reviewText: This game was never actually finished before it was abandoned by the developer so that he could start work on a second game. The store page continued to promote features that were never implemented for months after it was clear that they were never going to be added to the game. Making matters worse, the developer has demonstrated extremely bad judgment when interacting with customers that shows a lack of professionalism. reviewText: Bought the game in the early days for full price, was listed as Multiplayer and promised many features. Multiplayer was NEVER added and none of these features we were told would be implemented, made it in to the game. Only to then sell this second game back to us again, at full price! Complete rip-off. Now we're left with nothing but a broken demo. I will NOT be buying the second game and funding such a dirty, cheap money making scheme and I'd advise that others do the same. The only way these developers will learn NOT to cheat their customers, is if they have no custom. As bad as EA as far as I'm concerned.

reviewText:
Sometimes you find a game for $1.00 on HumbleBundle and think why not, I'll give it a shot.  What's the worst that could happen?  It sucks and you're out a dollar?  Don't be a fool.  Listen to me, I used to be like you...naive.  I paid the dollar, positively gitty at my thrifty yet philanthropic purchase, but I discovered there are far worse fates than not liking the game.  Oh yes, much to my dismay, I learned you could absolutely LOVE the game.  Specifically, I learned that someone, some magical gameweaver of a developer, had somehow discovered a way to craft all of my 4x RTS dreams into one perfect game.

Imagine having all this only to find out after hours of gameplay that the mystical Dev had just M. Night Shyamalan'ed your ♥♥♥ by abandoning the game deep in development, leaving gamebreaking glitches unpatched, and giggling all the way to the bank with your hopes and dreams.  Now there will forever be a void in my heart where the finished version of this game should be.  I would've rather spent my dollar on paying someone to kick me in the balls.  At least that paid would go away eventually.

To be fair, I'm only whining because I love what this game could've been.  Wasting that much potential should be a crime.  The finished, patched version would have been one of the best 4x games of all time.  Unfortunately this game was abandoned to begin development on a sequel that will be turn-based, not real time, and therefore more of a completely different game than a sequel.  While I love turn-based strategy, the RTS version of this game is the one I wanted and now I will never be able to play a polished version of it.  As such, I simply can not recommend it.

reviewText:
Edit #2: I'll just leave this here.

http://steamcommunity.com/groups/SDVC

An unofficial StarDrive group, where discussion is open and not censored. The Steam forum is pretty heavily moderated and the developer has a habit of deleting threads and banning people left and right before and during a big sale, so this is where people go to talk about the game however they like and not risk having their threads deleted because they didn't like the game.

***

I bought this game when it was in Early Access and... I thought it was amazing. Full of promises and ideas. Back then, the developper was promising updates pretty much left and right. Multiplayer was to be added to the game. Rare resources, laying mines, better diplomacy, being able to make joint operations with allies; all of these things were to be added to the game... But none -- NONE -- were implemented. The game you can buy right now is very much the same game I bought in Early Access, minus a few bugs. Hell, some core features such as the freighters are still buggy...

So, that being said, is this a good game? Well, it's an okay game. I spent several hours on it so obviously it's not totally terrible. But the thing is, most of these hours (I'd say two third of them -- yes, that much) was trying mods and messing around waiting for the content update to come. When the Developper announced that he screwed up and decided the game was done and could not be updated anymore because of engine limitations, I stopped playing altogether.

To make up for it, the owners of StarDrive will get a discount on his next title and access to some kind of multiplayer mini-game is going to be free. The thing is : his next game is going to be a turn-based strategy game. I bought a real-time strategy game. His next game is going to get as close to a MoO2 clone as he can. Good things for the fans, I guess, but that's not what I bought.

So, to sum things up: this game is half-finished, features are lacking, it lacks polish and is very, very rough around the edges and is developped by one of the worst indy dev ever as far as PR and I care for my customers" are involved. There are better games out there to spend your money on.

But hey
date:
that's just my opinion.

***

Edit #1: the multiplayer mini-game has been abandoned as well. Yes

reviewText:
This game had a ton of potential but was abandoned by the developer for greener pastures after he decided it would be good to start on a sequel while charging full price to everyone (including the people who have bought this unfinished project). It was initially released with a ton of bugs and still has many things that have yet to be fully fleshed out much less finished in any considerable degree. The ship designer and the battles that rarely take place are the only positives to take out of this game.

The diplomacy part of the game is very shallow indeed. With races declaring war on you with little motivation beyond your empire's progression crossing a line set by their predetermined level of aggressiveness. The same goes with positive interaction. It's very much a game of watching a bar go up or down to get them to do something you want to do.

Empire building is also shallow and unfinished. There is almost no internal management other than building a shallow level of building sets that make all your colonies resemble one another after only a colony or two. Rebellion takes place when your treasury drops below a certain level and only in this manner. Civilization 2 has more in depth internal management than this title.

Military matters are hampered by two things: The lack of any meaningful artificial intelligence and the small tech tree present in the game. The tech tree is the smallest tree I've seen in a 4x game (and smaller than some RTS games like Rise of Nations or even Age of Empires). The AI assembles the same, tired fleet makeup and then throws it at you. This means pretty much every single game plays out the same way regardless of the galaxy size. The one saving grace in enemy behavior is that the game saves your custom ship designs and then uses them against you in subsequent games should you choose another race to play as. I would love to see other 4x games incorporate this feature into their titles so I'm faced with much more difficult fleet makeups since they were designed by myself or other players who post their designs for others to use.

All in all, I'm very disappointed in not only the way this game turned out, but the developer's behavior on the steam forums once people heard he was abandoning any serious development on the game on an interview. He would ban people who warned others about the state of development and has had meltdowns on multiple gaming forums when confronted about the issue. Do not give your money to this studio. Other 4x's like Galactic Civilizations II or Distant Worlds do this genre much more of a service.

reviewText:
The game has a good concept, the ship designer is fantastic. However, the game is NOT FINISHED. The author abandoned it to work on a sequel instead of finishing what he started.

The game is missing:

Any meaningful construction on planets.

Detailed Tech Trees.

Balanced 4x elements (it's very easy to break balance on spies in particular, and impossible to do well on high difficulties without large spy bonuses really).

Proper debugging.

Multiplayer.

Although if this game had been finished it could have been very good, it has not been, and I would NEVER buy another product from the same author. If you're interested in this game, I would consider pirating it, getting a copy from a friend, or some other method that avoids paying the author. The ship designer is still fun to play with as long as you install one of the large mods that adds in a lot of the content that the game is missing.

reviewText:
A fun, aesthetically pleasing space strategy game that is simply awesome!

Or atleast it would be if crucial game elements were fixed.

As it stands, 02-02-2014, several game features are severely lacking in polish and there are some design flaws that really jump out - such as any unmonitored battle being auto-calculated without taking into calculation such things as ship armour or shields, etc. which essentially makes the elaborate, fully customizable ship designing pretty much redundant.
Or the way that the AI can win the game without warning due to building a late-game Wonder-style building, which you recieve no notification of until it is already built and the game has ended with your defeat (though this building can be disabled by modding. But it's supposed to be a feature-complete, finished game, right?).

The game still do not feature alterable gameplay options, leaving you with only the options of adjusting video and audio.

The game's features such as customizing races are great, and the shipyard ship-designing is really fun - but if it doesn't matter in the slightest, it isn't really that much of a draw, is it?

I don't really think that I can recommend this game as it is at this stage. It has a lot of really cool stuff going for it, but when crucial elements of the game remains broken, that's really just bad. When (hopefully) they have been fixed or have become toggable (as indeed some of the problems seem to stem from the developer's design decisions), the game is definitely something to recommend.
But not in its current stage.

reviewText:
This game was a dream. A fine product in the making with aspirations for greatness. We, the ones who bought in early in development, had further dreams of playing this complex and (even in early stages) fun game.

Then it started. Features began to be stripped off the list due to engine limitations (I might add that other early access games have successfully carried out full-engine ports when the limitations of the initial engine became apparent and at no additional expense to the existing financial backers...). The dreams and promises slowly turned to ash in our mouths as this unfinished and limited product got promoted out of beta (some having suggested just in time for sales to boast visibility...).

I gave up on this product completely. I wouldn't have thought about it again had I not accidentally clicked into it's forum (I was aiming for Starbound). What do you want from Star Drive 2?"

In summary this product is a promise. It is a shadow of what it could have been and it is well-and-truly abandoned; as even IF the developers take the time to add an additional patch simply to avoid it being permanently labeled 'abandonware' my confidence in the devs doing anything to address any additional bugs (least of all those that are likely to be added into the game by a half-arsed
date: smoke-and-mirrors patch) is nil.\n\nA grave disappointment all round and I truly wish the best for any whom buy into this product (or other products) as I feel burned by this developer and wouldn't wish that upon them."

reviewText:
Forgoing all my past issues with the game, I'm going to focus on one specific feature that is missing.

Ingame, deletable, saves.

The code for such is already in the game, with one being able to delete custom ship designs, but you can't delete your saves.

And depending on how much you play, the space taken up by the saves can get rather large. And given that you have to do through a, by default, hidden folder to reach the saves directory then not everyone is going to know how to manually delete them.

I've wiped my saves folder a few times. The first was after Pre-Warp mode was released. I wiped three gigs of save files. The next was after I decided to start using Tech Level Mod, and I wiped 2 gigs worth of save files. Eventually, I wiped those saves out as well clearing out roughly 3 gigs of space.

I wiped my save folder again recently, hadn't done it for a long time, and got rid of 6.3 gigs worth of saves. Counting all these saves, I had roughly 14.5 gigs worth.

That's practically the size of a completely new game. And if I didn't know how to reach the saves folder, I'd have never thought about cleaning the folder out because well... how large can something as simple as save files get?

Given how much space you can eventually rack up in saves, it's rather sad that Stardrive doesn't include a easier way to get rid of them.

reviewText:
I's a 4x made as a real time strategy game. Although you can pause and set the speed to 4x normal (although it would be nice if it could go even faster).

The UI stinks. You can't control planetary production or spies as a whole, in groups, auto-repeating, etc. It becomes very grindy just setting up production clicking to add, next planet, click to add, next planet, etc. There's way too much of that crap.

The game crashes in longer games.

The game doesn't handle too many ships very well. It should really have a unit cap or something but it doesn't and so you can build too many units and mess up your gameplay.

There's no multiplayer.

The AI interaction sucks. There's not much you can get the AI to do. You can't really coordinate anything with them. It is a shame since 4x games are fun to play cat and mouse with the npcs and pit them at war with each other.

Also when you get someone to join your alliance they become part of your race or whatever and they vanish out of existence and you just control all of their units. This also reduces the amount of AI interaction because everyone either joins with someone you don't like or with you and then it's just a 1 v 1.

There's a lot of other reasons why this game fails. I have to admit...it is a great genre and the real time space fights especially since you get to custom build them (although it's not as good as it could be but that's another issue) are really fun to watch...but in the end, there are just a waterfall of shortcomings that make this game something nobody will remember.

Get it if it is super cheap like a few bucks and you like 4x and RTS. There aren't many RTS crossed with 4X so it's still nice to play for a bit.

reviewText:
developer abaondoned this to anounce stardrive 2 without ever finishing many of the in game functions and content. my system could start the game, but many of my friends could not even get it to start. their posts in the dev forums went as problem solved. there is a huge memory problem that causes a crash even on my system after a couple hours of play. many crybaby ideas in forums turned most of the game content into nurfs instead of real balancing. the playable races only a few had full ship trees while the rest were place holders. developer money grab attitude has given me the policy to not support indie projects. rather have a company take control of the project and hold people accountable for my dollars.

all that out of the way the game even in its unfished form was extremely fun. if you can actually get it to run and play up to the 4 hour limit on single game then stardrive is gonna be a good time. ship customization is unparalleled. and if you can get over the fact that the other races are not and will not ever be finished then who cares. if you can look pass numerous dead ends in the games ui or story function because this project was abandoned for stardrive 2... then you gonna have a good time. for 30 bucks i wouldnt do it theres other fun out there for that kind of money. if it goes on sale id say pick it up. steams good like that.

i ultimately would not recommend supporting a game that gets abandoned for a sequel. if track records go this way then i would lookout for anything in the future with names attached to it from members of this project. early access never again.

reviewText:
This game showed promise. It really could have been a fantastic game, yet the problems with the final product force me to not recommend it.


Why?
A game match cannot be completed reasonably. Towards the end game there are huge framerate issues/lag that literally bring all ship movement to a near halt . Lots of good gameplay aspects, unfortunately the game is unfinished. Quests are incomplete, ship models are not implemented for some races(The wolf race), and the developer has no intention of finishing/fixing it. What boggles my mind is the developers decision to make a sequel. How could anyone reasonably expect the sequel to be any more of a complete product than this ?

reviewText:
I played this promising game when it was still on Early Access. At the time, it was a very good looking EA full of potential. Artwork was pretty awesome and in the line of Master of Orion and the 4X real-time game concept was pretty interesting (MOO meets Sins of a Solar Empire?). Ship customisation was nearly as in-depth as Galactic Empires V (less techs/weapons, but firing angles matter) and loads of good ideas were there in the making. UI was a bit awkward, but still functional once you had a grip on it and it did not seem impossible to improve.

Nearly 3 years later I decided to see how it evolved. Well, it did not. At all.

I read the negative reviews and I understood why. The dev went to make the sequel Stardrive 2 instead of delivering a good product. Apparently, that sequel is even more ambitious (yet reuse most of the Artwork) but also even more flawed, unpolished and unfinished). Basically he repeated the same pattern.

It is very sad this Zerosum had 2 golden chickens in his hands and instead of collecting eggs over decades, he chose to break their necks and eat them immediately. That is pretty unwise in my opinion, but whatever floats his spaceship... still, I didn't buy Stardrive 2 and may never do.

reviewText:
(6/10) (Turn based 4x fans)
(8/10) (Real time strategy fans)

Could have been an amazing turn based game, instead the dive into real time gameplay had some innovation potential but overall served to just bring the overall game down for me, removing the thoughtful nature of play that I am after with 4x games.  Instead of carefully planning each turn and building each world, you are constantly under the gun to move as fast as possible and blaze through reflexively.  Its a shame because otherwise the style and production of the game is quite high and would have more than carried it for me for a long while.

(Admittedly, I really do not like RTS play to begin with, and my main score reflects coming into the game expecting it to have been a turn based 4x title along genre norms.  The second score applies for people who do prefer the more highly energetic RTS style gameplay over turn based strategy)

reviewText:
I'm a pretty big fan of space games in general, and the idea of StarDrive caught my attention. Wow, a real-time 4X game? Sounds great!

...

It's terrible!

I don't like to have to say this about a game that I put money into, but it has to be said for the good of humanity / the steam community. But why such a harsh approach?

1. The interface lacks any polish. It's bad, everything is hard to manage. You will feel the pain once you are 10 minutes into the match as it becomes impossible to manage anything. There is no good notification system and you will probably neglect something important for a good 5 minutes of the game.
2. The game isn't finished. Yep, it's broken. There are many bugs left in the game and it is NOT feature complete as it says on the steam page. Yes the game is playable, that does not mean it's done. Many of the features the developer promised never made it into the game, and he is making no effort to fix any of the issues the community has presented. Which brings me to my next point.
3. The developer has abandoned the game. He has ditched the project and is now working on StarDrive 2, which is basically StarDrive 1 but actually polished. The developer has even gone to the extent to delete all threads which criticize the game. So now everything on the community page looks positive and isn't showing the truth about the game. Luckily he can't delete steam reviews, so I have one last hope to convince you the reader to save your money for a better game.
4. The game is just over-priced! I mean really. There are so many better games for half the price or even less. It's not even worth the money. Please buy a real game. The developer himself said this was his 'experiment'.

reviewText:
Although my favourite genre is Space 4X I only played Stardrive recently despite tracking the game throughout.

Compared to games such as Distant Worlds Universe I did not find Stardrive immersive at all as it was very uneventful with a limited storyline.  The AI was weak and it very quickly became an AI curbstomp in my first game while still learning the mechanics.  The game is strategically shallow.  There is an obvious need to spam troops.  A good technology tree is essential and this game was distinctly lacking in that respect.  The ground invasion mechanic is very simplistic.

The ship design is cool.  The combat is okay but I vastly prefer Sins of a Solar Empire.  I didn't really notice any of the bugs and missing features that some people go on about but then for $8 my expectations were low.

The Developer takes an extremely hard line to Moderation which is often unfair and unreasonable.  I've recently seen a poster banned and all his posts deleted despite the fact not a single forum rule was broken.  Some of my posts have also been deleted despite also never breaking a forum rule.  Unfortunately the Developer is stuck in the habit of shooting himself in the foot with respect to the future of his own community.

http://steamcommunity.com/groups/SDVC/discussions/0/

I really don't understand why some consider the game groundbreaking. I would rate Distant Worlds Universe, Endless Space, Galactic Civilisation 2 and Sins of a Solar Empire Rebellion all as significantly better games, each in their own way.  You can see the potential but a lot is unrealised.

There are patches but they are very slow and limited compared to games like Distant Worlds Universe.

There is hope with the Stardrive Extended Mod and perhaps there will be a vastly improved effort with Stardrive 2.   It's possible I could really get into them so I'll stay involved.

Post Review Note: Along with others I have now been banned and all my posts deleted despite breaking no forum rules. Be warned.

reviewText:
Was a promising game, got it cheap so I didn't care, but I advertised it with some friends and I feel bad right now. I virtually shelved it in my library and waited patiently for good updates to come but they never did, and the game was released unfinished, development was stopped and the dev got away with all the money.

Now he's making a 'sequel' which I know I won't be buying unless the recommendation ratings are 90% and above, which is unlikely.

A lot of promised features are not present, even some existing features are not fully completed. The game runs bad on my rig after a long session. Visuals are good, but that's about it. Browsing the forums and checking it out again recently, it seems that modders are still trying to make the game work, which is nice, but I still wouldn't recommend it to newcomers.

Thank god I still have GalCiv 2 and GalCiv 3 soon

I don't blame the Early Access model, it's there for games like Kerbal Space Program, in which I would lose approx. 1000 hours of fun if it the model hadn't existed. For games like Minecraft, Starbound, Arma 3, GalCiv 3, etc

In the future I would be more careful about buying early access games unless the ratings are 90% Positive and above, and the game is already feature complete, Thanks Enhanced Steam for that extra data! ratings right now are 48% positive 52% negative, bad.

reviewText:
This game is one of those without fully realized potential. I haven't even been able to load the game in months, it just crashes.

When it works the game plays beautifully and it's everything I wanted a space brawler to be.
But persistent problems with stupid AI, rampant memory leaks, random crashes, and other bugs make this game nearly unplayable without community mods. Unfortunately installing the best community mods often introduces yet more crashes.

I would not recommend buying this game, nor will I ever support this developer. As soon as he had his money he stopped what little patching he did and ran off to develop his next game. I get that it's exciting to work on new projects, but it's also important to keep the loyalty of your original fan base.

reviewText:
Hello fellow gamers.

When i first saw Stardrive i thought that this will be very cool, a little different 4X game.
At the very first glance we got everything:
- Sci Fi theme
- Space battles
- Development of our Empire
- Ship design

The formula for most 4X games is simple. We explore, expand, exploit and exterminate. Easy right? Most 4X games are turn based- but not a Stardrive. It is real time.
When i firstly heard of it i thought cool! it will have more dynamics"
Boy.... i was so wrong.

StarDrive is semi finished game.
I know- hundreds of gamers wrote it in their reviews. But i don't mean bugs
date: no update for.... ever.\nI meen there are only few techs
recommended: some about 5-7 buildings to go on planets
hoursPlayed:
few ships.
And thats not all!
The galactic is very empty space- sure there are some pirates and aliens but this is about it.
Nothing more.
So what we really get from buying this game?
Pretty decent ship design tool.
O! and the treading cards.
....
Well music is nice but there is no additional soundtrack so we actually have to play this game to listen to it......
And the dynamic of play i was thinking about?
Nope. This game is slower than most of the turn baset games.
So....

Plus:
+ very good alien graphics
+ space looks nice
+ music
+ ship designer
+ space battles are nice
Minus:
- well you bought a demo of beta version of game
- bugs
- no joy
- slooooooooowwwwwww and boring
- where is content  ????

I'm big fan of SciFi and i adore 4X genre and i have to say:
Don't buy it. Please. DON'T"

reviewText:
It pains me to admit but I don't recommend this game.

I'm coming up 100 played on this game and I will probably play more as personally I enjoy playing StarDrive but I can not in good conscience recommend buy this title to even my vile enemies. Unless its on Sale, then it may be worth it if you enjoy this type of game. If I we're you however, right now considering buy StarDrive, I would spend my money of Galactic Civilation 3. It's the same game has this, in fact I would say this game is a bad copy of Gal Civ 2 which is a 'banging' game, although not as graphically nice as StarDrive gameplay is so much better. So if you can afford it Gal Civ 3. if you want to save money gal civ 2. Anything but StarDrive.

Right, so I've had a rant but objectively what wrong with the game. Weirdly not alot. It crashes for time to time normally because I'm tabbing out but autosaves stops that from been a big issue, and few minute roll back max is not really anything to get worked up over. The AI is bad, there are times that it seems slow and dumb, not even able to get off the starting planet. Other time as soon as they make contact they declare war and within 5 mins I have two invasion fleets heading to two different systems, this with the first 20mins of the game. I suppose you could agrue a degree of dynamic realism with the AI but it doesn't feel like that it just seems break. Hypo active somethings and hyper active other times never a good balance. The Gameplay is very long but that not really a fault of the game, more the genre. The tech tree is a bit bland as it's a standard tech tree discuss what race you play has.

In final conclusion; I enjoy playing the game, it has some nice features to it and a good about of variety when it come to ship design and weapons. However the game feels unfinished whenever I play Stardrive I have fun but i'm not satified and its for that reason I can't recommend it.

reviewText: I have played many 4X games, all of Master of Orion series, Endless Space and few others, so StarDrive was a must test. I liked the videos and screenshots, but actually playing it did not deliver. 15 minutes was all i could stand. The controls and UI are simply horrible. Buttons are small and spread wide across the screen borders. Font is plain and tiny, you can't scale them up. All the info is big masses of this tiny text, from which you need to gather information of what's happening, what means what. At the point i was simply trying to move camera around the galaxy, i quickly noted the developer hasn't learned anything about mouse controls from other games. Most of the general mouse functionality, such as simply dragging would have made it much better. Does he expect me to use arrow keys to navigate the map? But it was time to quit game before actually seeing any space combat, shame.

reviewText:
Sometimes you find a game for $1.00 on HumbleBundle and think why not, I'll give it a shot.  What's the worst that could happen?  It sucks and you're out a dollar?  Don't be a fool.  Listen to me, I used to be like you...naive.  I paid the dollar, positively gitty at my thrifty yet philanthropic purchase, but I discovered there are far worse fates than not liking the game.  Oh yes, much to my dismay, I learned you could absolutely LOVE the game.  Specifically, I learned that someone, some magical gameweaver of a developer, had somehow discovered a way to craft all of my 4x RTS dreams into one perfect game.

Imagine having all this only to find out after hours of gameplay that the mystical Dev had just M. Night Shyamalan'ed your ♥♥♥ by abandoning the game deep in development, leaving gamebreaking glitches unpatched, and giggling all the way to the bank with your hopes and dreams.  Now there will forever be a void in my heart where the finished version of this game should be.  I would've rather spent my dollar on paying someone to kick me in the balls.  At least that paid would go away eventually.

To be fair, I'm only whining because I love what this game could've been.  Wasting that much potential should be a crime.  The finished, patched version would have been one of the best 4x games of all time.  Unfortunately this game was abandoned to begin development on a sequel that will be turn-based, not real time, and therefore more of a completely different game than a sequel.  While I love turn-based strategy, the RTS version of this game is the one I wanted and now I will never be able to play a polished version of it.  As such, I simply can not recommend it.
voteText: 236 of 248 people (95%) found this review helpful 71 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Edit #2: I'll just leave this here.

http://steamcommunity.com/groups/SDVC

An unofficial StarDrive group, where discussion is open and not censored. The Steam forum is pretty heavily moderated and the developer has a habit of deleting threads and banning people left and right before and during a big sale, so this is where people go to talk about the game however they like and not risk having their threads deleted because they didn't like the game.

***

I bought this game when it was in Early Access and... I thought it was amazing. Full of promises and ideas. Back then, the developper was promising updates pretty much left and right. Multiplayer was to be added to the game. Rare resources, laying mines, better diplomacy, being able to make joint operations with allies; all of these things were to be added to the game... But none -- NONE -- were implemented. The game you can buy right now is very much the same game I bought in Early Access, minus a few bugs. Hell, some core features such as the freighters are still buggy...

So, that being said, is this a good game? Well, it's an okay game. I spent several hours on it so obviously it's not totally terrible. But the thing is, most of these hours (I'd say two third of them -- yes, that much) was trying mods and messing around waiting for the content update to come. When the Developper announced that he screwed up and decided the game was done and could not be updated anymore because of engine limitations, I stopped playing altogether.

To make up for it, the owners of StarDrive will get a discount on his next title and access to some kind of multiplayer mini-game is going to be free. The thing is : his next game is going to be a turn-based strategy game. I bought a real-time strategy game. His next game is going to get as close to a MoO2 clone as he can. Good things for the fans, I guess, but that's not what I bought.

So, to sum things up: this game is half-finished, features are lacking, it lacks polish and is very, very rough around the edges and is developped by one of the worst indy dev ever as far as PR and I care for my customers" are involved. There are better games out there to spend your money on.

But hey

reviewText:
This game had a ton of potential but was abandoned by the developer for greener pastures after he decided it would be good to start on a sequel while charging full price to everyone (including the people who have bought this unfinished project). It was initially released with a ton of bugs and still has many things that have yet to be fully fleshed out much less finished in any considerable degree. The ship designer and the battles that rarely take place are the only positives to take out of this game.

The diplomacy part of the game is very shallow indeed. With races declaring war on you with little motivation beyond your empire's progression crossing a line set by their predetermined level of aggressiveness. The same goes with positive interaction. It's very much a game of watching a bar go up or down to get them to do something you want to do.

Empire building is also shallow and unfinished. There is almost no internal management other than building a shallow level of building sets that make all your colonies resemble one another after only a colony or two. Rebellion takes place when your treasury drops below a certain level and only in this manner. Civilization 2 has more in depth internal management than this title.

Military matters are hampered by two things: The lack of any meaningful artificial intelligence and the small tech tree present in the game. The tech tree is the smallest tree I've seen in a 4x game (and smaller than some RTS games like Rise of Nations or even Age of Empires). The AI assembles the same, tired fleet makeup and then throws it at you. This means pretty much every single game plays out the same way regardless of the galaxy size. The one saving grace in enemy behavior is that the game saves your custom ship designs and then uses them against you in subsequent games should you choose another race to play as. I would love to see other 4x games incorporate this feature into their titles so I'm faced with much more difficult fleet makeups since they were designed by myself or other players who post their designs for others to use.

All in all, I'm very disappointed in not only the way this game turned out, but the developer's behavior on the steam forums once people heard he was abandoning any serious development on the game on an interview. He would ban people who warned others about the state of development and has had meltdowns on multiple gaming forums when confronted about the issue. Do not give your money to this studio. Other 4x's like Galactic Civilizations II or Distant Worlds do this genre much more of a service.

reviewText:
Do not buy Stardrive. This game is an unfinished product. It is, at best, “glitchy”. It's an “early access” with no chance of being fixed. Apparently, for reasons beyond the developer, he isn't allowed to work on the engine of the game any more, or something.

This is rather sad because the game needs optimization, badly. The controls and interface of the game aren't adequate. It makes an obtuse game with a steep learning curve even more convoluted. Basic RTS controls, like finding idle workers or rally points aren't implemented. At least one technology in the science tree doesn't work as described. Ships, especially freighters, lack a good path-finding, making them delay deliveries of vital goods, but it happens to offensive fleets too. Trading technologies requires you look up, -or know the cost by heart-, of everything in the science tree or risk the ire of the IA. The planet managing screen lacks clarity and the possibility for quick changes. The ship building interface refuses to show critical information, like the rate of fire, the global ammunition consumption per second or the global energy consumption. While it can be nice to figure out this puzzle, you have to recalculate everything as soon as you improve your design with new technologies. Having to look up the wiki for vital weapon-data is also unforgivable for a game that requires such precision in its main mechanic from the player. Personalising larger ship becomes a tedious chore.
Speaking of ship building, while it is nice to modify them depending on your style, it doesn't take into account how the game works as a whole. The IA isn't a big threat later on in the game as much as it is in the beginning, and that can be circumvented as soon as you realise what variable the computer uses for it's moves: the size of your fleet. Just build a big fleet, and you've won. You don't even need to research, or spend hours personalising cruisers. In the end, it is completely pointless, because you will already be winning by the time you get to bigger spacecrafts, making their puzzle-like personalisation moot and time wasting.
Worse, this system isn't as open as it pretends to be: you cannot build viable ships if you deviate from a certain type of fighter. If you are thinking of building a huge flying fortresses which shoots at everything in all directions, think again: one ship attacks one ship. Sure, the area of effect damage might hit others too, but that's leaving it up to chance, or worse, the IA. The attacks your ships employ are always the same: charge! There is an option to turn on a “broadside” tactic but it doesn't work according to the forums.
When you get right down to it, the changes you make to your ships are quantitative, not qualitative. You decide the weapons and the defences, and how much of each, and then try to figure out the best way to power the whole thing and keep sufficient ammunition. In essence, this more open system is just more complex than the one in Endless Space, replacing the straightforwardness of it with inconvenient and pointless creation tools. Also, Endless Space has more tactics during the combat phases, with three different phases, defining tactics for each, heroes and hero abilities. In Endless Space, the ships are not just flying towards each other like a Middle Age jousting competition.

It's a shame since Stardrive sounds good on paper. A better IA and path-finding across the board would have gone a long way. An IA that changes tactics depending on difficulty, rather than giving it a boring bonus to resources to compensate for it's inadequacies, would also give a more organic and challenging experience. Being able to annexe other civilizations peacefully by building a federation is great but removes diversity from the game world, by having the player taking control over the planets and fleets of the ally, making end game seem even more without challenge when you suddenly control half the map.

Finally, on a positive note, the aesthetic of the game, the design of the races and the ships, are very pleasing and enjoyable even thought there are basically references to other media (like the Wing Commander series, the mythos of Cthulhu, the Asari from Mass Effect, etc.). The mixture of all the references kind of creates its own style. The rest of the game though needed a lot more polish.

reviewText:
The game has a good concept, the ship designer is fantastic. However, the game is NOT FINISHED. The author abandoned it to work on a sequel instead of finishing what he started.

The game is missing:

Any meaningful construction on planets.

Detailed Tech Trees.

Balanced 4x elements (it's very easy to break balance on spies in particular, and impossible to do well on high difficulties without large spy bonuses really).

Proper debugging.

Multiplayer.

Although if this game had been finished it could have been very good, it has not been, and I would NEVER buy another product from the same author. If you're interested in this game, I would consider pirating it, getting a copy from a friend, or some other method that avoids paying the author. The ship designer is still fun to play with as long as you install one of the large mods that adds in a lot of the content that the game is missing.

reviewText:
A fun, aesthetically pleasing space strategy game that is simply awesome!

Or atleast it would be if crucial game elements were fixed.

As it stands, 02-02-2014, several game features are severely lacking in polish and there are some design flaws that really jump out - such as any unmonitored battle being auto-calculated without taking into calculation such things as ship armour or shields, etc. which essentially makes the elaborate, fully customizable ship designing pretty much redundant.
Or the way that the AI can win the game without warning due to building a late-game Wonder-style building, which you recieve no notification of until it is already built and the game has ended with your defeat (though this building can be disabled by modding. But it's supposed to be a feature-complete, finished game, right?).

The game still do not feature alterable gameplay options, leaving you with only the options of adjusting video and audio.

The game's features such as customizing races are great, and the shipyard ship-designing is really fun - but if it doesn't matter in the slightest, it isn't really that much of a draw, is it?

I don't really think that I can recommend this game as it is at this stage. It has a lot of really cool stuff going for it, but when crucial elements of the game remains broken, that's really just bad. When (hopefully) they have been fixed or have become toggable (as indeed some of the problems seem to stem from the developer's design decisions), the game is definitely something to recommend.
But not in its current stage.

reviewText:
This game was a dream. A fine product in the making with aspirations for greatness. We, the ones who bought in early in development, had further dreams of playing this complex and (even in early stages) fun game.

Then it started. Features began to be stripped off the list due to engine limitations (I might add that other early access games have successfully carried out full-engine ports when the limitations of the initial engine became apparent and at no additional expense to the existing financial backers...). The dreams and promises slowly turned to ash in our mouths as this unfinished and limited product got promoted out of beta (some having suggested just in time for sales to boast visibility...).

I gave up on this product completely. I wouldn't have thought about it again had I not accidentally clicked into it's forum (I was aiming for Starbound). What do you want from Star Drive 2?"

In summary this product is a promise. It is a shadow of what it could have been and it is well-and-truly abandoned; as even IF the developers take the time to add an additional patch simply to avoid it being permanently labeled 'abandonware' my confidence in the devs doing anything to address any additional bugs (least of all those that are likely to be added into the game by a half-arsed

reviewText:
Forgoing all my past issues with the game, I'm going to focus on one specific feature that is missing.

Ingame, deletable, saves.

The code for such is already in the game, with one being able to delete custom ship designs, but you can't delete your saves.

And depending on how much you play, the space taken up by the saves can get rather large. And given that you have to do through a, by default, hidden folder to reach the saves directory then not everyone is going to know how to manually delete them.

I've wiped my saves folder a few times. The first was after Pre-Warp mode was released. I wiped three gigs of save files. The next was after I decided to start using Tech Level Mod, and I wiped 2 gigs worth of save files. Eventually, I wiped those saves out as well clearing out roughly 3 gigs of space.

I wiped my save folder again recently, hadn't done it for a long time, and got rid of 6.3 gigs worth of saves. Counting all these saves, I had roughly 14.5 gigs worth.

That's practically the size of a completely new game. And if I didn't know how to reach the saves folder, I'd have never thought about cleaning the folder out because well... how large can something as simple as save files get?

Given how much space you can eventually rack up in saves, it's rather sad that Stardrive doesn't include a easier way to get rid of them.

reviewText:
The developer's a lying sack of ♥♥♥♥, which I suppose has never been entirely uncommon in the game industry. Unfortunately, it's not like the days of old where a game like Big Rigs would simply cause an entire company to go under, and hopefully many of those people went on to work on real games, or committed suicide.

No, this is the glorious age of crowdfunding, where ♥♥♥♥nuggets like the guy who made this game can tell you that a feature will be included, then not only fail to do so, but obtain enough support to create a second version of the game. Not even a sequel. A second version of the game that will be sold at full retail price.

So what happens if you own this version of the game? You get like, a 20% discount on the new one. That way, if you're actually ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ enough to buy it, you can have two different versions of the same game in your Steam library: one unfinished, the other with the promised features for the first(maybe; I wouldn't hold my breath). It's like if every patch for every game were released as a separate version of a game and you had to pay for all of them.

There isn't even an entire company behind this game. It's just like one dude. Jesus. Let it go under so he'll go back to accounting or whatever the ♥♥♥♥ he did before he became a professional thief.

reviewText:
I's a 4x made as a real time strategy game. Although you can pause and set the speed to 4x normal (although it would be nice if it could go even faster).

The UI stinks. You can't control planetary production or spies as a whole, in groups, auto-repeating, etc. It becomes very grindy just setting up production clicking to add, next planet, click to add, next planet, etc. There's way too much of that crap.

The game crashes in longer games.

The game doesn't handle too many ships very well. It should really have a unit cap or something but it doesn't and so you can build too many units and mess up your gameplay.

There's no multiplayer.

The AI interaction sucks. There's not much you can get the AI to do. You can't really coordinate anything with them. It is a shame since 4x games are fun to play cat and mouse with the npcs and pit them at war with each other.

Also when you get someone to join your alliance they become part of your race or whatever and they vanish out of existence and you just control all of their units. This also reduces the amount of AI interaction because everyone either joins with someone you don't like or with you and then it's just a 1 v 1.

There's a lot of other reasons why this game fails. I have to admit...it is a great genre and the real time space fights especially since you get to custom build them (although it's not as good as it could be but that's another issue) are really fun to watch...but in the end, there are just a waterfall of shortcomings that make this game something nobody will remember.

Get it if it is super cheap like a few bucks and you like 4x and RTS. There aren't many RTS crossed with 4X so it's still nice to play for a bit.

reviewText:
developer abaondoned this to anounce stardrive 2 without ever finishing many of the in game functions and content. my system could start the game, but many of my friends could not even get it to start. their posts in the dev forums went as problem solved. there is a huge memory problem that causes a crash even on my system after a couple hours of play. many crybaby ideas in forums turned most of the game content into nurfs instead of real balancing. the playable races only a few had full ship trees while the rest were place holders. developer money grab attitude has given me the policy to not support indie projects. rather have a company take control of the project and hold people accountable for my dollars.

all that out of the way the game even in its unfished form was extremely fun. if you can actually get it to run and play up to the 4 hour limit on single game then stardrive is gonna be a good time. ship customization is unparalleled. and if you can get over the fact that the other races are not and will not ever be finished then who cares. if you can look pass numerous dead ends in the games ui or story function because this project was abandoned for stardrive 2... then you gonna have a good time. for 30 bucks i wouldnt do it theres other fun out there for that kind of money. if it goes on sale id say pick it up. steams good like that.

i ultimately would not recommend supporting a game that gets abandoned for a sequel. if track records go this way then i would lookout for anything in the future with names attached to it from members of this project. early access never again.

reviewText:
This game showed promise. It really could have been a fantastic game, yet the problems with the final product force me to not recommend it.


Why?
A game match cannot be completed reasonably. Towards the end game there are huge framerate issues/lag that literally bring all ship movement to a near halt . Lots of good gameplay aspects, unfortunately the game is unfinished. Quests are incomplete, ship models are not implemented for some races(The wolf race), and the developer has no intention of finishing/fixing it. What boggles my mind is the developers decision to make a sequel. How could anyone reasonably expect the sequel to be any more of a complete product than this ?


I cannot reccomend this game as it was personally dissapointing for me, the developer is incompetent/Shady ,and this is not a finished product.

Don't waste your money.

reviewText:
I played this promising game when it was still on Early Access. At the time, it was a very good looking EA full of potential. Artwork was pretty awesome and in the line of Master of Orion and the 4X real-time game concept was pretty interesting (MOO meets Sins of a Solar Empire?). Ship customisation was nearly as in-depth as Galactic Empires V (less techs/weapons, but firing angles matter) and loads of good ideas were there in the making. UI was a bit awkward, but still functional once you had a grip on it and it did not seem impossible to improve.

Nearly 3 years later I decided to see how it evolved. Well, it did not. At all.

I read the negative reviews and I understood why. The dev went to make the sequel Stardrive 2 instead of delivering a good product. Apparently, that sequel is even more ambitious (yet reuse most of the Artwork) but also even more flawed, unpolished and unfinished). Basically he repeated the same pattern.

It is very sad this Zerosum had 2 golden chickens in his hands and instead of collecting eggs over decades, he chose to break their necks and eat them immediately. That is pretty unwise in my opinion, but whatever floats his spaceship... still, I didn't buy Stardrive 2 and may never do.

reviewText:
Here we are, months after purchase and hours into the game.

So much potential, squandered, wasted.

ZeroSum games was basically a one-man studio, with what seemed like a desire to bring back a great space-4X in the vein of games like Masters of Orion.  Oh, the disappointment.

It started great.  Bought this on early access, it had some problems, a couple major ones in fact, but it was close enough that you could see the point of it all, even then, and could see the few hops and leaps it'd take to get the foundations in place and really start cranking out an awesome game.

Instead, what we got were sweet nothings and empty promises from ZeroSum, tales of how we would get X Y and Z features or fixes.  Trade is still broken, warping still doesn't work properly, warp nodes and defensive emplacements are still prohibitively expensive, the AI is still crap and consistently allows itself to get rolled over in stupid and meaningless ways, often outright killing themselves due to what should be only one or two MINOR circumstances regarding their worlds and infrastructure...  No balance, no design, no polish, the damn game isn't even finished.

ZeroSum took a game, created a clear image, started tapping serious potential...  And then turned around and flipped their entire customer-base for this game the bird.  Zero literally said he would fix the problems and get the game working...  After saying this, he never even got around to the first major gameplay problem, the broken Freighters...  And then announced StarDrive 2.

Do not buy this game, do not support ZeroSum games, do not support Iceberg Interactive until they drop ZeroSum, because at the very least, ZeroSum Games is nothing more than a shady, cash-grab studio who does not deserve to be called a Games Developer, and Iceberg deserves to same insults and utter lack of respect for as long as they intend on keeping such a disingenuous, malicious individual/studio under their umbrella.

StarDrive is a game to AVOID AT ALL COSTS.

reviewText:
(6/10) (Turn based 4x fans)
(8/10) (Real time strategy fans)

Could have been an amazing turn based game, instead the dive into real time gameplay had some innovation potential but overall served to just bring the overall game down for me, removing the thoughtful nature of play that I am after with 4x games.  Instead of carefully planning each turn and building each world, you are constantly under the gun to move as fast as possible and blaze through reflexively.  Its a shame because otherwise the style and production of the game is quite high and would have more than carried it for me for a long while.

(Admittedly, I really do not like RTS play to begin with, and my main score reflects coming into the game expecting it to have been a turn based 4x title along genre norms.  The second score applies for people who do prefer the more highly energetic RTS style gameplay over turn based strategy)

reviewText:
I'm a pretty big fan of space games in general, and the idea of StarDrive caught my attention. Wow, a real-time 4X game? Sounds great!

...

It's terrible!

I don't like to have to say this about a game that I put money into, but it has to be said for the good of humanity / the steam community. But why such a harsh approach?

1. The interface lacks any polish. It's bad, everything is hard to manage. You will feel the pain once you are 10 minutes into the match as it becomes impossible to manage anything. There is no good notification system and you will probably neglect something important for a good 5 minutes of the game.
2. The game isn't finished. Yep, it's broken. There are many bugs left in the game and it is NOT feature complete as it says on the steam page. Yes the game is playable, that does not mean it's done. Many of the features the developer promised never made it into the game, and he is making no effort to fix any of the issues the community has presented. Which brings me to my next point.
3. The developer has abandoned the game. He has ditched the project and is now working on StarDrive 2, which is basically StarDrive 1 but actually polished. The developer has even gone to the extent to delete all threads which criticize the game. So now everything on the community page looks positive and isn't showing the truth about the game. Luckily he can't delete steam reviews, so I have one last hope to convince you the reader to save your money for a better game.

reviewText:
Warning - this is long

I found Stardrive ages ago and saw a lot of good things about it.  It was in alpha/beta though and Steam was nice enough to point me at the products webpage, because as handy as steam is they cant list all of a products features on their little webpage (I dont think it had the read more tabs at the time).  Looking at the developers product page and seeing youtube videos of what you are going to purchase is just good consumer behavior so that you know what you are purchasing.   It looked really interesting and offered things such as

Moo2 like but RTS 4x
Multiplayer
Create your own fleet designs
Special Missions in which you assume control of an individual ship instead of a whole side
A sandbox mode with an engaging storyline.
Neutral factions like remeneant and pirates
A variety of random Galaxy events.

Shortly after buying in the developer said he was temporarly removing multiplayer to work out the kinks. Of course the sandbox storymode wasnt finished yet but thats ok it was in beta and we saw how it was going to work with researching technologys and contacting a neutral planet and yadda yadda.  And watching the WTF is, along with other videos I knew what to expect with late game latency, so when people bashed on it I spoke up for it, telling people to give it time.  As a one person developer a 1-2 year wait for him to fix things up was acceptable.  Especialy for a game that had already been in development for something like 4 years.  But it was nearly done,  so we should hold on before making judgements.  I made guides, tried to help people out,and gave suggestions.

But the longer it went on the more sour it got.  A couple weeks out of its -short- Beta when we could no longer get refunds there was a 50% off sale.  A couple months after that we were told Multiplayer would never make it to the game and that maybe in a stardrive 2 we would get it.   Special missions were abandoned all together.  The Galaxy events were restricted to simple planatary shifts for fertility/richness.  The Remenent story-arc was removed (and then later reintroduced in a shoddy manner).  Some of the AI's were just left in a crippeled state.   And then afterall of that there was a Fertility/abundance nerf across all difficultes (that the AI ignores) that you cant disable... Why nerf fertility/abund in a single player game?  A -lot- of players got banned from the message boards for silly things and it was a pretty rage induceing time all around.

But thats ok I thought,  I decided to give him more time.  He said development would 'slow' while stardrive 2 was in development but we could expect improvements.  I decided to wait for SD2 to get finished before looking back and seeing what has changed.

So this last week I gave it a try again.  And I have to say i am not very happy with it.  I enjoyed the game more during beta and after 'release' with the late game slowdown then I do now.  Sure some small bugs were fixed with fire arcs and its a little bit smoother.  But several AI's just sit there and let other AI's conquer them with out putting up a fight, several races just refuse diplomacy of any sort (usualy the ones that are conquering other ai's),  and the AI still cheats up the wazzoo building fleets it cant possibly support.  And overall it feels really bad fighting over a 4 population planet with a 1.2 fertility and 1.1 richness because thats the best there is out there.

In the end the game currently (may 2015) feels unfinished (even more so then during beta), and in need of a good AI patch, a balance patch, a few new galaxy option sliders to combat what was done post release, and maybe a gamemode paid DLC.

I'm gratefull for the 33% discount on SD2 for SD1 owners,  its a nice gesture.  And I really do hope SD2 turns out well, and can compete with other games in the turn based strat genre. But in the end this game also made me deicde to hold off on SD2 until its cheep as dirt.. because no matter how good it looks 'now'  it could be a lot worse in 6 months.   And thats just not something I ever really expected to say about a game.


ps- yes I know my spelling sucks. Hopefully it wasnt too bad.

reviewText:
It does not matter what anyone else tells you: this game is not finished and has been abandoned by the developer. It will never be finished nor its bugs fixed. Some of these bugs are game-breaking and there are many features that are either incomplete (to name but one: game mode. You can choose it when you start a new game, you get to choose only one option, though -_-) or inexistant.

Now to the game itself, it is an ok game that appears to be a rip-off of a lot of games, but the ship designer as well as space battles are genuinely fun. I would almost call the initial ships being crappy a stroke of genius since it gives you a nice challenge to build good ships for each faction and possible tech configurations etcetera, this part is really fun. The automation of building them is ok, and putting them in fleets is very nicely done with the fleets manager.

The gameplay itself, not so much. You initially start with one planet, and the one whom colonizes the most suitable planets the first is generally the first to win. If your race has improved metabolism that is every planet with 0.8+ fertility. Mind you those planets tend to be rare (10-15% of all colonizable planets I think?), which only makes it worse that you can also choose to make your race cybernetic. Combine that with industrious and improved metabolism and suddenly your requirements have changed to all planets with 0.8+ production instead (assuming 20-25% tax rate). This basically means 75% of all colonizable planets, most of them being uninteresting to other races except the Opteris (cybernetic), mainly for this reason, that race can actually pose a challenge in the hands of the ai.
Granted, you can research stuff to make all planets viable for colonization or bother with crappy food transportation, but that goes against colonizing fast.

So combat: by default, you are at peace with every race. If you have troops/fleets in orbit of each of their planets cabable of annihilating them in a few seconds they will not care. If they intercept one spy they are likely to declare war, but with war you get space battles! Still, if you choose the best possible strategy, there will be no space battles: as long as your military strength is higher than your opponents', only the Opteris will ever dare attack you. And even when it is not, half the ai players will generally just seek peaceful relations (pacifist/cunning/honourable ais). There are also planetary battles: capturing planets through troops. Troops cost no maintenance, though, so flooding each of your planets with troops is a sure way to win: the ai will never bomb your planets.

Remember the game-breaking bugs? One of them involves unlimited production! It involves having shipyard, you spend 10 spare production on a ship, get 13 invested, cancel it, and now you have 13 spare! The shipyard effect even stacks with multiple shipyards, so I don't think I need to tell you how horrible it is to leave this bug in the game.

Overall I give this game a 4.0/10
Kicking dumb ai asses does make me feel better, but you are better off with something like Distant Worlds.

reviewText:
Although my favourite genre is Space 4X I only played Stardrive recently despite tracking the game throughout.

Compared to games such as Distant Worlds Universe I did not find Stardrive immersive at all as it was very uneventful with a limited storyline.  The AI was weak and it very quickly became an AI curbstomp in my first game while still learning the mechanics.  The game is strategically shallow.  There is an obvious need to spam troops.  A good technology tree is essential and this game was distinctly lacking in that respect.  The ground invasion mechanic is very simplistic.

The ship design is cool.  The combat is okay but I vastly prefer Sins of a Solar Empire.  I didn't really notice any of the bugs and missing features that some people go on about but then for $8 my expectations were low.

The Developer takes an extremely hard line to Moderation which is often unfair and unreasonable.  I've recently seen a poster banned and all his posts deleted despite the fact not a single forum rule was broken.  Some of my posts have also been deleted despite also never breaking a forum rule.  Unfortunately the Developer is stuck in the habit of shooting himself in the foot with respect to the future of his own community.

http://steamcommunity.com/groups/SDVC/discussions/0/

I really don't understand why some consider the game groundbreaking. I would rate Distant Worlds Universe, Endless Space, Galactic Civilisation 2 and Sins of a Solar Empire Rebellion all as significantly better games, each in their own way.  You can see the potential but a lot is unrealised.

There are patches but they are very slow and limited compared to games like Distant Worlds Universe.

There is hope with the Stardrive Extended Mod and perhaps there will be a vastly improved effort with Stardrive 2.   It's possible I could really get into them so I'll stay involved.

Post Review Note: Along with others I have now been banned and all my posts deleted despite breaking no forum rules. Be warned.

reviewText:
STARDRIVE.

The little 4X that almost could..


For starters, i must voice my bias. Towards grand-stategy and 4X-Games. They have been my personal guilty pleasure for the longest time. However, even with the enjoyment i get from them. There are examples of the genre that are not exactly the best and unfortunately StarDrive falls to that category.


This is easily explained, the game is dull. Bloody dull...  In all of my 140+ Hours of playing it, i have completed it only thrice.
And every time, the end-game played out the same. Every single time, not counting the time i went all Borg with the Opteris. This is mainly due to design issues with the Tech- political- and AI-systems, they feel unfinished and in many ways they still are. The game still crashes now-and-again and some of the mods that have been made for the game only make it even more unstable. (This just might be only on my end, but its still a noteworthy issue.)

And for a game that is aesthetically very similiar to the good old Master of Orion series, the problems only make it worse. Since in its core, the game is broken and even with the patching the developer has done (and if memory serves it was just one guy.) the game is still broken.

And i'm really sad about it, since the idea is so good. A spiritual successor to Master of Orion, with better graphics, sound and all the other fluff. StarDrive tries to be that game and in some ways it has succeeded, but the technical and design issues are the things that kill the experience, not to mention the pacing.

In all, StarDrive is a decent game. Even with all of its obvious problems, it is somewhat enjoyable. But not by much. It gets dull really fast and with the pacing being off, i really doubt that you could squeeze more than few playthroughs out of it. And even the modular ship building system, can only squeeze so much fun out of it.

StarDrive.

I think a C , is the best grade i can settle for. This coming from the game being still mostly incompleted and the modding only helps so much. But to give a yes or no on the recommendation option, i think i still need to put a yes on it. Since Steam has no neutral"-option in the recommendation thing..

Furthermore
date: i would not recommend paying full price
recommended: buy this when it goes on sale. Since the content isnt there for 30€ (or regional equivelant.)."

reviewText:
Was a promising game, got it cheap so I didn't care, but I advertised it with some friends and I feel bad right now. I virtually shelved it in my library and waited patiently for good updates to come but they never did, and the game was released unfinished, development was stopped and the dev got away with all the money.

Now he's making a 'sequel' which I know I won't be buying unless the recommendation ratings are 90% and above, which is unlikely.

A lot of promised features are not present, even some existing features are not fully completed. The game runs bad on my rig after a long session. Visuals are good, but that's about it. Browsing the forums and checking it out again recently, it seems that modders are still trying to make the game work, which is nice, but I still wouldn't recommend it to newcomers.

Thank god I still have GalCiv 2 and GalCiv 3 soon

I don't blame the Early Access model, it's there for games like Kerbal Space Program, in which I would lose approx. 1000 hours of fun if it the model hadn't existed. For games like Minecraft, Starbound, Arma 3, GalCiv 3, etc

In the future I would be more careful about buying early access games unless the ratings are 90% Positive and above, and the game is already feature complete, Thanks Enhanced Steam for that extra data! ratings right now are 48% positive 52% negative, bad.

reviewText:
This game is one of those without fully realized potential. I haven't even been able to load the game in months, it just crashes.

When it works the game plays beautifully and it's everything I wanted a space brawler to be.
But persistent problems with stupid AI, rampant memory leaks, random crashes, and other bugs make this game nearly unplayable without community mods. Unfortunately installing the best community mods often introduces yet more crashes.

I would not recommend buying this game, nor will I ever support this developer. As soon as he had his money he stopped what little patching he did and ran off to develop his next game. I get that it's exciting to work on new projects, but it's also important to keep the loyalty of your original fan base.

reviewText:
Hello fellow gamers.

When i first saw Stardrive i thought that this will be very cool, a little different 4X game.
At the very first glance we got everything:
- Sci Fi theme
- Space battles
- Development of our Empire
- Ship design

The formula for most 4X games is simple. We explore, expand, exploit and exterminate. Easy right? Most 4X games are turn based- but not a Stardrive. It is real time.
When i firstly heard of it i thought cool! it will have more dynamics"
Boy.... i was so wrong.

StarDrive is semi finished game.
I know- hundreds of gamers wrote it in their reviews. But i don't mean bugs
date: no update for.... ever.\nI meen there are only few techs
recommended: some about 5-7 buildings to go on planets
hoursPlayed:
few ships.
And thats not all!
The galactic is very empty space- sure there are some pirates and aliens but this is about it.
Nothing more.
So what we really get from buying this game?
Pretty decent ship design tool.
O! and the treading cards.
....
Well music is nice but there is no additional soundtrack so we actually have to play this game to listen to it......
And the dynamic of play i was thinking about?
Nope. This game is slower than most of the turn baset games.
So....

Plus:
+ very good alien graphics
+ space looks nice
+ music
+ ship designer
+ space battles are nice
Minus:
- well you bought a demo of beta version of game
- bugs
- no joy
- slooooooooowwwwwww and boring
- where is content  ????

I'm big fan of SciFi and i adore 4X genre and i have to say:
Don't buy it. Please. DON'T"

reviewText:
StarDrive is one of those games that looked good and innovative when it was in development, but ultimately fell short of expectations once it was released. The game was released fairly quickly - some would say a bit too quickly - and while it did receive several significant patches and updates after release, the post-launch development was not nearly as comprehensive as the community, in my opinion, deserved. As of the writing of this review, ZeroSum Games has already announced that they are making a sequel. Maybe it's just the cynic in me, but it seems as though this first game was really little more than a test run designed to iron things out and bilk some folks out of the money that the studio decided they needed to create the 'real' game. I can only hope that this sequel does more to address the issues that StarDrive had and provides a more satisfying 4x experience.

Even at the supposed 'end' of its relatively short development cycle, the game still suffers from a number of glitches and bugs, as well as incomplete or poorly-executed gameplay systems. Ships and fleets often suffer from poor pathfinding and an inability to carry out simple orders. Up until the last update, the few 'random events' that made up the in-game 'storyline' were still incomplete or did not work properly. The lack of any sort of scaleable engine technology or range limitations on your ships pretty much allows any player to scout out the entire map in the blink of an eye, destroying any sense of gradual exploration and leaving you susceptible to zerg rushes from any 'warmonger' races you have the misfortune of rolling up a new game map alongside.

Planet development, research, and economics are serviceable but pretty bare-bones. The short tech tree is ridiculously easy to blow through with 'standard' pacing, and really needed to be at least 50% larger than what it was; several branches were seriously underdeveloped. Terraforming is almost nonexistent and the greatest variety of planet facilities is in defenses; there are no more than two or three facilities each for farming, industry, and research. The economic system had the potential to be quite intricate with its system of freighters physically transporting goods between planets; however, the limit of only three resources (food, industry, people) and the seeming lack of promised effects from the economic-related techs don't contribute to a realistic economic model and make it hard to afford much infrastructure.

Game setup doesn't provide a lot of options compared to other 4x games (Endless Space, GalCiv 2, and MoO2 - which this game purports to be emulative of - come to mind). Even the largest map size doesn't seem to be quite big enough, particularly given how sparse most star systems are and how many turn out to be crap - which, given the lousy terraforming options, make meaningful expansion of your empire difficult. Locations such as volcanic and ice worlds, gas giants, and asteroid belts, rather than providing additional options, are instead little more than eye candy, contributing nothing of value to the overall game when they could've added whole new dimensions to the tech tree and gameplay.

The game's seven races are fairly original, for the most part - conforming to the usual tropes, but distinctive in their own ways, though some are considerably more derivative than others. The diplomatic options are good, if not outstanding, and  the responses provided in the course of shooting the breeze with a particular species are amusing, while providing a gist of each race's personality and culture - though there's not a great deal of background information to be gleaned during the course of gameplay. The diplomacy system gives you an idea of how a given species feels about you, but no feedback on what you can do to improve relations. Espionage provides a number of options for stealing or sabotage in a fairly good, time-duration assignment system that relies on hiring spies and advancing them in rank.

I do have to say that the game's ship design system is solid, allowing you to get down into the nitty-gritty of customizing each vessel to the last component. Everything comes down to power; each component has to be within range of a reactor or power conduit or it won't function. Design a ship with too many power-hungry systems but not enough power generators, and systems will shut down once its reserves run dry. Ship-to-ship combat happens in real time on the system maps (a la Sins of a Solar Empire) and hit detection and damage is location-based, with external systems taking damage first before the guts of the ship can be hit.

What this means is that ship design must be well thought-out and involves compromise. With only so many slots on a particular hull - and only so many internal and external slots available - you have to strike a balance between power systems, weapons, and defenses. Ships with heavy armor on the outer edges will have less space available for weapons ports; shield generators have limited coverage bubbles and must be positioned to protect the whole ship; reactors are volatile and will cause splash damage to surrounding components if they are destroyed - do you have the space to spare for internal bulkheads, or do you trust your ship's armor and shielding? Each weapon can be given an individual arc, allowing you to construct aggressive, maneuverable, front-heavy gunfighters or well-defended, multi-turreted line warships capable of massive broadsides - or anything in between. All that's needed is a way to lock each weapon in position so it can't be moved - errant clicks while upgrading or changing designs can skew a turret's alignment clear out of whack, which can lead to whole fleets with frakked up aim if you happen to not notice.

StarDrive does have some good points and interesting design features, but overall the game feels incomplete. I could go on about other aspects of the game that suffered from clunky design or thin or incomplete treatments, but the message has been stated - StarDrive is not worth picking up, at least not at this point. Clearly it has been popular enough to warrant a sequel, and hopefully the developer will take the time to get things right in the second game. StarDrive 2 definitely needs a far greater level of depth and sophistication in its gameplay if it wants to stand out from its competition in this fairly crowded field of space empire-building games, and needs to have the glitchy systems and underdeveloped features of its predecessor ironed out in order to deliver a satisfying experience. Hopefully the sequel will prove to be a game that greatly improves on its 'trial run' predecessor and is able to succeed because it is well-designed and provides deep gameplay options - something that the original game has not succeeded in delivering.
