reviewText: What at first seemed like a promising new addition to the 4X genre turned out to be a complete disaster.\n\nThe game is incomplete and the devs have since jumped ship to rebuild the game from scratch under a separate title, Stardrive 2". No has been compensated in any way
recommended:
unfinished mess is now being touted as a complete game.

As for the specific issues with the game:

PROS-

1. It is a 4X game played in real time. That allows for a number of new strategies not possible in the ordinarily turn-based genre.

2. Stardrive brought something new to the 4X table with the ability to design/fit your ships from scratch. This was the core pulling factor of the game. With customizable ships
hoursPlayed:
you could choose from a pre-existing hull and redesign the ship to suit whatever specialised need. Titanic capital ships dedicated to bombing a planet into a foetid hellhole (i.e. conducting Exterminatus)? Done. Beam cannons on a fighter? No problemo. Or how about a logistics ship to provide repairs to your fleet on the go? All possible.

CONS-

1. The Sunburn engine is a laggy unoptimized mess. The framerate basically commits suicide during mid to late game
voteText: and especially in the middle of large fleet battles involving more than a hundred ships

reviewText: I brought this 4x game a while back and was full of promise for what it had the potential to become, back then the developer was promising all sorts of intresting features in the form of updates and frankly they have not turned up in the quanity they should have. Now thats not saying this is a bad game, the ship customization and planet management is excelent and the combat feels like it should in space, but it just can't carry the game on there own. Wheres the Multiplayer? Story mode? Improved diplomacy? We were promised it but it just never materialized. Its a trend thats been happening for the last year with 'pay to play early' Alphas and Betas, and i honestly wouldnt of minded if the game had been continualy updated and polished. But it wasn't, It's AI feels buggy and will uterlly crush you on anything higer than Normal, balancing resource production is a NIGHTMARE, the game crashes after several hours play for no reason and Diplomacy isnt finished, just the classic 'give me tech and planets' approch or picking from a list of things your spys can do. The term 'cash grab' certainly has come to mind.\n\nIf somebody put another 6 months into polishing and actualy finishing this game it would be great, in its state now? Save your cash, go play Galactic Civilization II, SIns of a Solar Empire or Armada, that should cure your itch for space colonization for awhile.

reviewText:
Game is too easy for classic grand strategy (4X) genre in every aspect. You can learn all the tricks in mere minutes and there's not much to do after that.
Most annoying is the tech tree: it is just too shallow and all-visible at start (well, there's something like 1-6 upgrades in 1-3 tech trees in each of five tiers plus one 'hidden' tier). Upgrades are completely evolutional, improving just main characteristic of shield/armor/weapon/etc.
Space combat is really nasty too: no matter how much time you spend designing your ships combat result is mostly determined by ability to sustain DPS and hit the target (like a not-so-large pack of cheapest fighters with ammo-less lasers easily destroy something like cruiser). Moreover ships in fleet do not keep formation during combat thus there's no such thing concentrated fire or support ships staying in safe position delivering ammo/repairs to the hot zone.
As for diplomacy, well there's none out there. First Civilization had as much diplomatic choices as we have here and it is not the simplicity you want.

To be honest there's a couple of things that are good: it is ship designer (however you cannot fit your design with latest weapons/armors just developed by your techs, you need to do it manually) and 'turnless' strategic mode, however there're many space strategies which include these pros and doesn't have so much cons. If you want a good game, go for endless space (easy to learn) or something like space empires V or distant worlds (much harder thingies)

reviewText: This game was good at first, when i believed it was incomplete and still a work in progress, so much potential... Sadly, that went unfulfilled. The game seems to not want to communicate very well, with scant notifications or pop-up messages telling you whats afoot in your empire. The diplomacy is pretty light, though not the worst in the world. But for a game about ship combat, there's a surprisingly small amount of control, as aluded to earlier, you get no notifications when your ships are in combat, nor can you zoom to your ships or padlock ther camera on a ship (only your flagship and any ship you manually take control of) which makes the game seem incomplete. So many features seem unfinished or rushed and there's no word from the DEV on fixes or further development. The game looks exactly like Distant Worlds and attempts to play very similar but is a far inferior product and I'd reccomend that game over this any day, on account of it being a complete and enjoyable product, unlike StarDrive.

reviewText:
I'll be up front right now, I like this game. It offers a unique experience and I find myself coming back again and again to play it. That being said I would not reccomend it unless it was on at least a 75% sale as the game is not complete and pretty much never will be because the dev dropped it.

Now you can play the game, isn't broken you can play and finish a scenario but this game was abandonned and a lot of promises that were made were broken by the dev so there is lack of content and after a few games you get the gist of how things will go and the prospect of losing goes out the window even on the hardest difficulty. The Blackbox mod can fix this a bit but overall it's a problem. In addition you will suffer a lot late game due to poor optimisation that even a really powerful system can't power through. I put a lot of time into this game on my 3570k which was overclocked to 4.8Ghz and on the larger universe settings I still had significant slowdowns and juttering which can and will render the zoomed in direct fleet control unplayable. It basically leads to you sending massed fleets into enemy held systems and hoping that the AI can take care of things.

The best thing to do is the leave the universe size to normal and use the Blackbox mod to limit the number of ships the AI can have because if you don't you will quickly find that the AI will continue to pump out droves of ships and each one will make the game run a bit worse after a certain point. That being said if you have a recent Intel based chip(Sandy or newer) your system should easily be able to handle around around a thousand ships in the universe without significant slowdowns.

Probably my favorite thing about the game is the ship customization. In a word it's friggin cool and it really makes you feel good when your ship you designed is good enough to take on three or four ships of an equivalent class of ship and come out on top. That is I think the thing that really keeps me coming back because I keep finding better and better ways to build my ships and it feels really engaging.

To wrap up this game had loads of potential but it was let down by poor choices made by the dev in both the way they made the game and how the handled the abandonment of it. It is in no way worth the standard $30 asking price, you can pick it up for the unique experience but only if it's less than $10.

reviewText:
OK this is getting long so don't buy this game. It's buggy and shallow with few saving graces. After 57 hours of gameplay I can say without a doubt it was not worth the $7.50 I paid for it.

I wanted to like this game. It has a lot of things I like but it is too frustrating to play. I spent the first five hours of this game just figuring out how to play, finding a good path up the tech tree, creating an initial build queue and understanding the UI to be decent player. That's was OK because I thought after I had that down things would get better but as time went on it just left me on a plateau and I was no more satisfied than when I first figured out how to play.

Things I did enjoy- fitting your own ships with armor, weapons , subsystems and powergrid. Terraforming an ice planet turns it into an ocean planet. The artifacts are a nice touch and assimilation is very useful but comes too late in the tech tree becasue it is not retroactive.

My first successful empire was based on the good luck of finding a planet with 5 thought crystals. This gave and immense boost to my research abilities and I was quickly outpacing the computer. So whipped up a good ship design and threw it into production immediately and soon I had a decent size fleet ready to be mobilized on anything and I learned my first combat lesson just as quickly. Projectiles and missiles suck pretty hard in this game and energy beam weapons are way overpowered.

Why? Projectiles miss quite often and require ammo to use which means less space on your ship for armor/shield/powergrid mods and require resupply unless you have the painfully slow ammo fabricator. Missiles are slow and are easily avoidable if you maneuver your ships away from them and also require ammo. Beam weapons almost never miss (I had a beam weapon miss a few times when I paused the game and gave an order to attack then unpaused and the computer fired all weapons even though I was facing the opposite direction from my target? Still haven't figured that one out.) and require no ammo so making a good beam boat or two pretty much seals victory every time.
Also want to touch on the phased ordinance" tech here as this tech allows for a 50% chance of projectiles penetrating shields. You can unlock it twice so you can get 100% penetration but the first unlock is waaaay to early in the tree and there is only one other tech cheaper to start. It seems this was done to compensate for the low hit ratio of projectiles but it just breaks the game for shield users way early on. Don't even get me started on projectile armor penetration as well.

So I went back and rebuilt my ships with beams and ventured back out this time to steamroll everything in sight and that was pretty fun. After the initial wave of attacks I had reduced my enemies fleet to just freighters and they never seemed to recover. They never built another fleet of any size comparable to the first and this happened every time in every game I played with every race. You have one good fleet fight with the AI and its GG from them.

Also found out the hard way to never EVER press escape in the fitting window with the arcs overlay. I thought escape would drop the overlay and put you back to the fitting window while actually it will drop you from the fitting screen entirely without the chance to save your design. I always did the weapon arcs last so I lost a few good designs to an errant key press and I quit the games a few times doing that. The escape key is not consistent in the UI and lead me to believe it was more a "go back" button then a "close window" button.

And don't forget completely broken ground combat where if you take over from the AI and move your own guys it will allow your troops to automatically fire on each other as if they were the enemy and you have no way of stopping them until the unit dies!! Grrr!!!"

reviewText:
Could be fun, but has a non-existant tutorial. I had no clue how to design my ships, Plus you can't look at pre-made designs to get an idea or upgrade them. It does have a explanation area when you click the question mark, but it really don't explain much, especially about ship design.

Their idea of an epic sized galaxy is a joke. Also all planets are exactly the same size since they all had the exact amount of space to build on.

I had trouble with setting up fleets, after a while you get gargabe graphics and have to get out of the window to clear them. When adding ships to a fleet, they don't actually move into the fleet area until you move the fleet which makes no sense to me.

You have is a planet manager, however all you can do in it is to tell the AI what planets to colonize. You can't even use it to  move to individual planets. I had to scroll around on the map to find my home planet so i could give build orders.

Building anything is this game takes forever. My 3 hours of fame at 4x, all I managed to do is colonize roughly 20 planets and build some facilities and ships. There just doesn't seem like there is a lot of variety of buildings. Oh and you only get to build one of each on each planet.

I couldn't find a way to stop time, just hit random keys until something happened. Mostly ran is at 4x  until I got bored and quit.

I didn't understand a lot about this game and frankly I don't care, it's got too many issues to be a fun game. I was just bored or frustrated most of the time. Glad I got it in a bundle, sure as hell not worth the 30 bucks they're asking for it. Read somewhere that it was abandoned by it's dev for a sequal and that the sequal is just more like an update.

reviewText:
Wow. Stardrive. So sad. Early access is a double-edged sword. On one hand, you get to watch a promising game grow into something really special. On the other, you have Stardrive: A great concept lead by a thief. We were promised bug fixes, more content, and multiplayer. Instead, the dev took our money, discontinued development on this game, and moved on to Stardrive 2. He promises a 33% discount on the sequel for everyone who bought into his scheme. He will not be getting anymore of my money. It's a shame really as the game had a lot of potential.


As it stands Stardrive is okay. Not great. Not good. Just okay. A real-time 4x with fully customizable ships? Sounds awesome! It totally would be if it wasn't for all the game-breaking bugs, stupid AI, performance issues, and lack of multiplayer. All of which were promised to be addressed before the dev took our money and ran.

For around the same price you can grab countless other 4xs that are worth your time and are made by people deserving of your money. Let this game be a lesson to always be wary with early access titles.

reviewText:
This is one of those games with a lot of potential, and also one of those games that never quite lived up to it.

The premise is simple. The game takes place on a 2d plane. Your ships can be customized and designed very similar to Gratuitous Space Battles. Any wacky ship design you want, you can build. The game is also highly mod friendly, which is a huge plus in my book.

You colonize planets, design ships, build fleets, and conquer the galaxy. Simple enough.

Problem is that the game is highly buggy, full of memory leaks and other instabilities. This is a real shame considering how brilliant the game design is. There is just no polish and little to no bug fixing that was done. Be prepared to have your game either slow down to an unplayable crawl and/or crash to desktop continually.

Lots of potential but poor execution. Avoid this game unless you like frustration.

reviewText:
StarDrive is an immersive RPG. The amount that goes on in this game after a while starts to get crazy.

The concept is simple... zoom in and out with the mouse to view the star systems. The navigation that this game play provides is smooth and allows you to get to which system you need to view. The managing system of seeing all of your empires/planets and being able to allocate production is sophisticated enough but the user interface for it was done simply and made easy to use. Diplomacy can work for or sometimes quickly against you with an opposing empire declaring war. Trade routes, non-aggression pacts, war declaration, and even colony claims can be through diplomacy. Planets come in different varieties such as gas planets, Terran, swamp, barren and a few variants. Be sure to start exploring early and claim good planets, but doing so exposes you to aliens. You will find yourself addicted to this game after a while if you like micro and macro managing planets and a multitude of ships. You are also able to create your own ships (from colony ships to cruisers) and the creation system is a neat one at that. There is also an in game fleet design system that by itself makes the game much more easier to play (and to defend against enemies).

Why I support this game even though it has a lag issues (sometimes with and without the mod) is there is a community out there trying to improve this game. Moreover and more importantly for me, you are able to control a SINGLE UNIT and tell them what to fire. You can't say exactly which guns to use, but none the less this is the right idea in my mind to create a new genre : RPG meets first person shooters. Literally, any unit that's out there, choose to control. I wish more games did this in the sense. Imagine playing Starcraft and you can control a marine. Your marine that you are controlling dies so you automatically jump to the next one or go back to the RPG screen. This to me is brilliant and perhaps even game changing in the future.

I will have to give it a

RATING : 7.9/10

Due to lag issues and a need for a mod but either than that I recommend it - especially on sale. Just be extremely wary about the lag issue.

reviewText:
I love this game. When I bought it I just left it and never played for about 6 months. But when I picked it up and modded it with Tim's mod,  couldn't stop playing, I haven't had any problems with it, though that might just be because I have a gtx970. And with that mod it was amazing. However, the developer is a bit of an idiot. He has abandoned the game to go on the a sequel. WITHOUT COMPLETEING THE FIRST GAME!!! (but it will have much better land combat, but no more real time space combat :( ) As well some of the promised features never ended up in game, and I would really, really love multiplayer! (which was promised) And finally, the ship design system is awsome and is completely modular so youu can change, edit and completely remake every ship. As a result, I belive you should either try this game for its realatively unique real time space (most other 4x games do this due to preformance problems) or wait for the sequel for a hopefully improved game.

Edit:
I'm now more optimistic(watched thexpgamer's video on it) about stardrive 2 cause it does have real time combat, but you can only place ships right in front of the enemy and can't get reinforcements in battle. So I might try and mod that in if it isn't that hasn't been done already(pasted directly from my comment, sorry for gramatical issues)

reviewText:
Stardrive is a really good game, though with a few rough edges.  It seems to run fine until late game area where it will lag (on any computer) a good deal.

The develoment is done for it unfortunatly but you can get the blackbox un-official patches from https://bitbucket.org/CrunchyGremlin/sd-idk/overview

Blackbox is still pumping out updates to make the game better and better.  I would have liked to see some multiplayer though or even some more fleshed out storyline (the game has a kind of story you can figure out as you play).

The races you meet have very unique looks, especially the space samuri bears.  The ships look and feel amazing and each one can be totally customized and upgraded with research and the shipyard.  With stardrive 2 coming out soon though I might just hold off buying this one and get the sequel (which should have much more added in).
All in all I will be buying the sequel, so that should tell you how much I like this game.

I'll be patching it here and there as my whims take me. If you feel cheated by StarDrive

reviewText:
I have been playing this game since its beta release and i think its fair to say this game could have been so much more

“Some omissions and flaws, but balanced by excellent alien races and ship design. A welcome addition to the crew.”

this says it all nicely but is largely understated. As a whole the management and construction of an empire works quite well but in combination with wonky AI; a civ 5-esque diplomacy screen with reduced options and strange reactions (allies will quickly turn hostile if the wrong trade is proposed); no counterspying option leaves you to get ravaged by enemy spies; many incomplete or just missing features; no multiplayer; and late-game performance issues (I play it on a laptop so it may just be that) the fun factor quickly turns to frustration late in the game.

A lot of features were also just left out, despite being advertised as either implemented or coming soon on the steam store, and will most likely never be implemented as Zero Sum basically dropped everything in development for the game and focused on the production of a sequel, leaving the first game feeling very incomplete

BUT there are many aspects that work quite well:

The shipyard feature, for example, is amazing. it allows you to arrange unlocked systems on a ship frame so you can create specialized designs (ie resupply, strike, scout, coloyization etc) and allows you to control thier performance levels.
too many systems bogs down the power supply, shields over armor can be a vulnurability and more massive means slower travel. to name a few things.

the game is visually stunning. you are able to scale the map from a galactic map down to a single star with orbiting planets. the alien races are all fantastically concieved and there are 8 playable races which can be customized to have a number of positive and negative traits upon starting a new game. each race has its own ship designs, and most of them have unique ground units

I really liked that this game was 4x so that The game flows continuously and allows space battles to occur in real time while the construction and research aspects are turn based progressions. i thought this system worked really well, especially since you can increase the time scaling up to 4x (or more, but not on my laptop) and speed up the slow early stages of the game.


Unfortunately the features that i liked did not make up for its short comings, for me at least, and it looks like they will be carried through to the sequel along with countless improvements/features that should have been in this game.

VERDICT: this game is not worth $33CAD
If this game appeals to you, then I would wait for the sequel
If you've read a fair number of reviews and still want to try it, then wait for a sale to drop the price to $5-10 as there are some mods out there that really add a lot to the game and the game is still enjoyable

reviewText:
This game involved a lot of really great ideas, all with terrible execution, clunky control, and a UI that makes you want to gougue your eyes out.


Ship design in this game might be the deepest ever attempted, but involves far more tedious wiring of power than engineering acumen. You'd almost certainly enjoy Star Ruler's much simpler scheme, which ends up achieving far more creative possibility, or GalCiv and skip the hour-long battleship design process entirely.

Automation? Sounds good, but the AI is pretty terrible at minding itself. If you want to get much done, you're forced to take it into your own hands, and deal with the horrid hotkeys, UI, and the rediculous WASD-control of ships, which makes them unavailable for scrolling around the map. You also can't click-drag. You're stuck with arrow keys or zoom-popping like a schizophrenic rabbit. If you want your empire to do its own thing(but also the way you tell it to), play Distant Worlds, because that game has true and almost total automation options that is as capable as the actual enemy AI(which can get rather brutal, unlike stardrive's rather easy bots).

Ship combat doesn't even look that good, or play well. If you want something with tactics, go play MOO, and if you want actual cinematic splosion glory, go GalCiv or endless space. Small ships are gross pixel blobs and large ships just tend to look like a bunch of sausages flopping around.

There is very little customization available other than the standard race min/maxing before a game starts. Want to slog through a massive galaxy of mostly barren worlds? nope. Want a quick fight between factions already up against each other's shoulders? too bad. Square maps that all play the same. Why not any other game I previously listed, some allowing you to play on 3-d barbell, spherical, or perpedicular galactic arrangements while all allow much more map control. Why was this overlooked?

So even if you actually get used to panning around on the arrow keys like a geriatric, navigate your way through obtuse and uninformative UI, and after spending hours plugging your ship's weapons into power sockets, what do you get? Well, you'll be dealing with micromanagement forever. Yep, like Civ5 lategame, but more like all game. Governors are idiots, and basically anything you want to do you're going to have to pause the game and painstakingly order it out so that fleet doesn't fly apart in transit and make sure you pay attention to your ground forces so they don't sit there for days doing nothing!

You don't so much play this game as try to bear it. No matter what your tastes, what you really want is something else.

reviewText: Multiplayer would make this game amazing, as would the ability to make an actual custom race (as opposed to customizing the races as presented). Even lacking these things, it makes for a fun game. It can take civilization levels of time to complete a game though, if you decide to go for all the races and maximum map size.\nAll that said, I would suggest definately getting this game if you can pick it up for 20 bucks or less. If you are a particular fan of space 4x type games, then paying full price isn't out of the question. Having control of building your ships And commanding them in combat is very nice.
voteText: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Star Drive

This is a pretty decent game. It runs in real time as do the space battles. Ships can be commanded in space battles for full control of targeting.

Ship design is really neat. Hulls come as is and may be filled with all sorts of space combat goodies. THis is a cool part of the game.

Tech research is pretty neat. There are not a lot of techs but what is there is good.

The alien races are all distinct and filled with personality. There is also cusomization for your race if you want it.

The developer moved on to their next game, Star Drive 2, and they are very active in that title. This game has all that is needed to wage war and conquer the stars. It may be missing some fleshed out things but the game is definitely playable and fun.

Oh, and ground battles are turn based with control over each troop. Pretty cool.

reviewText: A lack of a good tutorial makes this game very difficult to get into. Any 4X, complex strategy game should put a lot of effort into their tutorial otherwise they outcast newcomers to the genre. I'm not a veteran 4X gamer, but I've played my fair share. I eventually did sort of get the hang of everything, but the fact that I was forced to learn mostly manually made my choices very stilted and boring. Like I didn't want to declare war on anybody since I didn't really understand if I'd win or not. I also focused solely on economy because everything else seemed a bit more advanced.\n\nThat said, the game was pretty decent, I just have zero interest in learning a new 4X game without proper learning tools. I'll go back and play SoaSE before I play this again.

This game is only good with community mod project that squashes a vast majority of the bugs that can be found and substainally beefs up the AI in its competive play.

Other then that its a good game and really could have been made into something great, but the creator is too busy stealing from Master of Orion.

play it, but only with the community mod installed.

reviewText:
Despite all of the flak this game has received it is still a fun game to play. I missed the Kickstarter for this game but got it as soon as it was available. The game met every expectation I had for it and has been a huge time sink. The ways ships are designed is one of the best systems I have seen implemented in a game and one I wish other studios would adopt.

Now I did not have many of the problems mentioned by most reviewers so I may have been lucky in that regard. The few crashes I did have were after marathon sessions of 12+ hours of playing. Over the years I tend to encounter very few bugs or other issues in games so I may just be very lucky.

Some of the mechanics weren't well explained but a little trial and error would produce the answer. In my experience if no explanation or trial and error is needed to figure out how a game works then the game has been dumbed down and will offer very little.

I've seen a lot of complaints about the developer not finishing the game and other issues but it ended up being exactly what I expected it to be. Personally, I got my money's worth of entertainment from this game and then some. I have even recommended it to a few friends who have also enjoyed it.

reviewText: A lot of people dislike StarDrive. Most of those are upset that the developer apparently stopped working on this game before it was complete to start on the sequel. Some because the game is -- indeed -- in an unfinished state in some places. (The tech tree is incomplete, and the story-line is most definitely so: it stops advancing barely after it starts!) The game obviously has flaws.\n\nWith that said, I really like the game. Great atmosphere and animation, the shipbuilding is detailed and the combat is fun, the rest is adequate at worst. I was also hoping that the game would be finished, but -- if you like 4x games and the game is on-sale -- I'd definitely recommend the game.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: After reading through the piles of negative reviews, I just had to throw my 2 cents into the debate.  Initially I kept getting crushed every game, leading me to concur with negative review posse. However, after giving StarDrive a chance,I feel like it will depend on the individuals 4x gaming expectation. Although there are some issues, StartDrive is a little more nuanced in some areas than others have indicated,for instance, you can join or form alliances, develope a spy network to gain tactical advantage by stealing tech or by sabotaging rival civs covertly. Designing ship loadouts is cool cause it lets you upgrade your fleets tactical capabilities as needed to expand your empire,strengthen alliances and crush the opposition. I enjoyed using covert methods to aquire, or to sabotage a rival civ .I found that SD offers an unpredictable, quirky style that might change whats expected in a 4x space title. In summary SD marries an asymetrical  universe with challenging 4x game play, Stardrive marches to its own drummer  with some in game quirks, but I its worth the price of admission. By the way, the Black Box Mod expands player options and reduces a lot of the the unwanted quirks. I say buy it!!!

reviewText:
StarDrive, a really immersive and fun game you'll get hooked on almost immediately. Starting of as one of the sentient races, you need to colonize, harvest, supply and defend your very own existence from those who would crush it (in most cases, everyone!). Build and design your own layout of each ship, you can have multiple different designs, but remember that the more you put on it - the more costly it becomes.

You can customize your race's special benefits at the game lobby screen, although it's Single-player only, it has a lot of interesting play methods.

I sincerely recommend this to Sci-fi, Strategy, Slow-paced genre lovers. It won't let you down!

reviewText:
If I could give a sideways thumb, I'd give one.  I liked the game because it reminded me of Masters of Orion, except not turn based. That said, I'm willing to bet that there are games in the genre that pay MoO homage much better than this one.

The most striking thing about this game is it doesn't feel quite complete.  I was shocked to see that they were coming out with a sequel to it, mainly because I had a hard time believing that this game was finished.  Hours of playing it and I still haven't managed to finish a game.  They've released several updates for it, but the game still doesn't feel whole, even in its current state.

I'd really like to give this game a thumb up, but an overall feeling of incomplete game design, and rushed development ruin it for me.  A good game, but not a great one.  Definitely doesn't live up to the original that started the genre.

reviewText: Personally... I have to say I have had more fun it would seem than other when playing this game, however, most of the things I see them point out are valid, in that, the game is fairly bad for being a 4x game. Other games like Galactic Civilization and Sins of a Solar Empire I feel better fit and are better overall in tech research, interface, interaction, combat options, etc. However, that doesn't mean I dislike the game overall but if you are looking for a good space strategy I would personally look else where because there are better. I will lastly add that the thing I was most aggervated at was the teraforming as I normally enjoy them but it is just bad as it could take me and hour to get two or three squares open for industry and agriculture and it was a late game thing when, in my opinion, the pace of the game should have made it early to mid game. My favorite thing was the races and how they were designed not really a game thing I know (and I dont mean the A.I.) but i like the concept of them especially the bear and the race with the owl slaves as you can assist the owls in revolting. reviewText:
When I first purchased this game, I was very concerned when I read all the reviews. I should have known better than to purchase a game without reading the reviews. As stated by the reviews, the game was unplayable due to excessive bugs and lag when first downloaded. However, one thing that I have found very strange about this game is that the more you play it and the more you explore, the less likely bugs are to occur (kindof like the exact opposite of Minecraft). IDK if this happens on everyone's computer or if it is just a wierd quirk of mine, and I have no idea how this could happen in terms of programming, but for about the last hour of playtime (about at 10ish hrs.), I have never seen any lag or not registering clicks to the degree that I first experienced it in the game. I still have some pretty significant trouble with the game not registering my mouse clicks, but it has become at least playable, and the problem is now only a minor annoyance, unlike the total hairpulling frustration upon first download. Sometimes, due to lag, it still registers that I clicked on something that I moused over earlier, rather than what I actually have my mouse over at the time of the click. I wonder if a similar phenomenon caused the programmer(s) to think that the bugs were fixed when they were unable to reproduce reported bugs.

If you have the patience for the bugs, the game itself isn't too bad. The ability to adjust your species for tactical, RP, or mixed  gameplay allows you to play a species according to your own interpretation of how they are or what they could be. I prefer a much more strategic and magical Vulfen to the brutish, early-game swarmers version that they are set to by default (retaining their militaristic tendancies, because IMO Vulfen aren't really Vulfen if they are too peaceful, but upon player preferance this could be changed too). It does have a fairly Star Trek/Babylon 5 type feel, which I very much appreciate. Diplomacy is critical, and there is a high degree of intrigue involved (though taking the few abilities and technologies for intrigue that exist will make it very simple, as max rank agents can pretty much do as they please at this point, only occasionally getting discovered or even foiled but not killed). Players should keep in mind, however, that there are few guides to this game, and the videos that are out there regarding this game often do not involve enough information to really give you the feel for things. With no tutorials missions, you will likely be completely lost in the beginning, even with deep research. For this reason, I would advise setting up your first species to give you a large margin for error. Additionally, I found race customization to be very confusing initially, but once you get it, it is very straightforward.

I have come to enjoy the game in time, but I cannot bring myself to recommend this game for its current price. It is simply too high.
voteText: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I highly recommend this one. It is already well polished for an Early Access game and I daresay is better that some AAA titles that have been released in their final stages.

The races are varied and interesting on it's own and it even allows you to customize them to suit your own needs while still remaining in a somewhat balanced state.

The ship building is easy and fun, if I had one critique though, I wish there was a way to test my builds before seeing them utterly fail in battle because I didn't know how a module will react. That said, as it is now is plenty good enough to enjoy the game.

Pros:
- Playable and polished even in early stages, loads of fun to be had
- Races are a joy to behold as they are varied and rather humorous in their depiction
- Easy to learn, difficult to master makes this something even a newbie in the genre can pick up.

Cons: *but this could change*
- Currently, ship building doesn't have a way to test builds so guides might be necessary there
- Increasing tax doesn't seem to have any negative impact at the moment or no value for measurement (ex: colonist morale)
- Enemy ships don't display their insignia so it could take some practice to know who's fleet is whose in game.

reviewText:
I could go on for minutes apon minutes on how this game is dreary, drab and overpriced but I'm gonna keep it short. So lets begin.

While the game isn't buggy or unpolished by any means, it's because of the majority of it's design is absolutley awful, not to say everything is ♥♥♥♥♥♥, just most of it. Like the music, a fundamental part of any strategy game whether it's Master Of Orion or Civilization, the music is there to make you feel like a commander of a thousand fleets or a cultured world leader, and in both of the games mentioned the game does a great job doing that. But in StarDrive it's... uhhh... ♥♥♥♥. The music sucks ♥♥♥, It's a bunch of dreary melodies with a few space feeling instrumentals but all of them lack any sense of excitment. And that's the main problem, this game lacks excitment... or fun... or a reason to exist.

I like ProJared's description of the game in his One Minute Review of the game. Hopefully ProJared doesn't mind that I'm gonna quote him.

It's like they took Master Of Orion 2 and made it realtime and then SUCKED all the fun right out of it."

That sentence alone can describe the whole game. Really

reviewText:
I've had a couple stability and speed issues with StarDrive despite plenty of memory and being well over the GPU and CPU requirements for the game. Starting the game for example takes several minutes before I even get the intro videos everybody always skips.

Nonetheless, once in the game I generall have a great time. The AI can be overly aggressive, but it draws a good balance between races which attack weaker prey, races who declare war because they see you as a threat, and races who could be peaceful allies (on conquerable foes, depending on your gaming style.)

I'd like to see some small additions, like the ability to save custom race settings and either have them in a droplist or loadable from a file like they already have for custom ship designs.

I really enjoy StarDrive. If you like space conquest games, this one's a good buy.

reviewText: Good game really a ton of fun. You can design your own ships but the best is the titan class ships (could spend hours on just designing those) and later on even see enemy AI use them against you if you play a different race.Unfortunately the races don't seem to make a whole ton of difference since you pick you'r own perks, the only thing I can see different between them is that the ships are a different shape which is slightly disappointing. Most people do get hung up on the fact that they did in fact promise to make this a Multi-Player game and went back on their word. I do understand why they are mad and I'm upset with them as well. I probably won't pre-order their next game because of the fact his word can't be trusted. However this is a good 4x RTS space game so everyone should give this game a shot if they are into 4x games. As fun as it would be multiplayer I do greatly enjoy the single player portion they did deliver.
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
its a decent game, but not everyone will enjoy it.

Some parts of it could use more works from devs, but that's not gonna happen - they moved on to making next game which will have some parts similar to Stardrive.

What i liked a lot:
1.Ship design - very good, complex ship design. How you place stuff (armor, power, weapons, etc) really matters. Also very fun to do.
2. Combat - nice looking, dynamic combat.

What is not so good (can be fixed by good mods though):
1. Tech tree could be better.
2. The game has a very strong snowballing effect - each civ's development is exponential and so minor differences in how you/computer micromanges stuff can lead to massive difference between civs' development/power in mid and late game. Can go both ways - you or one of AI opponents will become massively owerpowered compared to rest of universe at which point it will be much less fun.

Also no multiplayer and there will not be any.


Would i recommend this game? - Maybe.
If you, like me, like detailed and complex ship design and lots of micro of both economy and combat in such single player games - then you will get a good number of hours of fun from this game even without mods. If so get it especially if its on sale.

For comparison, I like this game more then Galactic Civ II and Space Empires V, almost exclusively because of massively better and more fun combat and ship design system.
voteText: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: An excellent game! Very unique, although complex, an immensly fun time. After I got over the hefty learning curve (SINCE THEY DONT HAVE ANY USEFUL TUTORIALS!!!) I immediately fell in love with the game. Being able to manufacture my own ships for my own means is way more fun that I had imagined. Although there are some aspects to the game that is lacking, in particular the weak diplomacy system, the combat is thrilling, and taking over the galaxy is always a good time.\n\nCons, as I stated the tutorials are just non-existant. The AI can be predictable if not boring. And frankly I'm not sure why they even implemented their diplomacy system. Maybe I just don't understand it's mechanics yet, but after playing for nine hours I feel like I should've mastered it, assuming it was functional. The lack of options within the menu can be annoying, there are no difficulty settings. The AI just automagically decide how hard they want to kill you. There are still a lot of annoying bugs. Specifically speaking, large capital ships tend to get stuck" although their icons continue to move. Ships randomly decide they dont want to attack
recommended: I give this game an 8/10. I would definitely recommend it to anyone who is into large scale space battles."

reviewText: Basically its a space empires 4/5 with better graphics, also bears some resemblance to master of orion -> colony managment is quite similiar if nor borderline the same -> so if you liked those games you should like this one too -> but that said the game has some cons as well -> tech tree seems kinda limited -> but the game is highly modable via simple notepad if you care to do so (with some understanding how the coding works) so you can adjust it to your liking if you care to do so (imho a big plus), Ship behaviour can be annoying at times, also i find some control options to be lacking -> for eg you can select one cargo ship and set its destination and what should it carry but you can do the same en masse with several at once -> which can be annoying when you build 10 of them and have to adjust each one in the same manner aka takes time and it can get tedious, fighter bays cane be exaple of this -> i had 10 carriers -> and form each one i had to launch fighters manyally aka select it then click the icon in its tab -> you cant select them all and press one button for that -> it can be bothersome in battle conditions. Also colony managment can get tedious if you have a lot of them . So yes the game does have some flaws but imho its a good game also nice graphics ans sounds make it immersive -> im a great fan of this genre so i love it ;) but some ppl might not like it -> due to tediousness or relatively slow dynamic at first. Also the game dev moved on so expect no new stuff from him -> either mod it yourself or get some mods from the community.

reviewText:
Personally I have no clue why everyone rates this game so horribly. Took me a bit to get the hang of this game, but its frankly great. Has way more depth than Sins of Solar Empire for me. Love the spaceship crafter and I love the depth involved with each planets colonization. Each faction is very interesting and customizable.

This game doesn't need a beast of pc to run as well. The last note would be to buy the game when its on sale if your on the fence about the game. Watch some gameplay videos and that will really tell you if the game is for you. I also didn't run into a single bug/crash while playing.

I have no clue why so many pc gamers complain about wasted money on a game they spent 100 plus hours on when most games that cost 60 dollars only give you like 20 hours of game play.

reviewText:
So Stardrive has a lot going for it. The ability to design each ship piece by piece and then set their AI. Want a large slow ship with all weapons pointing forward to hammer other large ships? What about making it lighter and pointing all the weapons to the sides and have it strafe through destroying smaller ships? Swap out those weapons for fighter bays and launch swarms of fighter ships. Don't like cannons? Switch out to missiles or lasers. Load it with emp weapons to disable other ships or tractor beams to bring fast ships to a halt and rip them apart with cannon fire.

Each race oozes with their own personality. From samuri space bears to mechanical hive mind of the Opertis.

Build a grand empire of planets. Forge treaties and even a federation with long time allies. The diplomacy system is not ground breaking but quite adequate.

The only down side, and it's a big one, is the slow down you experience late game. No matter how beastly your PC is the game is going to crawl latter on when each race has hundreds of ships and are duking it out with each other.

reviewText:
This game is very unpolished, but still fun.
(A lot of things are fixed by two mods I use, the 'Black Box' mod and the Tech Level Mod)

1. Ship designing:
This is excellent; module positioning really matters in combat. If you fill the interior with lots of reactors, they'll blow up when destroyed and will probably destroy your ship from the inside out.
Shields are not 'all around' your ship but instead only protect areas they're near to, so don't forget to place lots of armour to soak up the hits that get through.
There really aren't enough ship hulls and modules; each empire only gets 1 hull for each hull type (i.e. frigate, cruiser, battleship, titan etc.). Reactors never get an upgrade. Sub-light maneuvering speeds are much too low.

2. AI:
The AI for the other players is poor - they don't expand very much and they have a tendency to get angry about every single system you colonise. They are very, very bad at fighting and will only cause you trouble if you ignore your military for the entire game (which they'll also taunt you for doing). Their art however is really nice and each empire has its own set of ship types.
There's a nice automation dialogue that lets you automate the building and usage of scouts, freighters, and subspace projectors.

3. Research:
Research feels a little slow for me. The tech tree is pretty sparse and could use some more mid/end-tier stuff.
There are two (maybe three?) 'discovered' secret techs which appear according to what you do in the game. This is something the developer never got around to adding more of, which is a real shame.

4. Early Access 'dev didn't implement X':
I hear this a lot, and it seems to make up most of the reviews here. This game does feel like the dev gave up when it was 80% finished. I didn't buy this game in Early Access (Humble Bundle had it for $4) so if you're not sure, buy this on sale.

reviewText:
I been wasting a ton of time(fun time) in fact about 354 steam record hours(not steam play throw in many more hours). I simply love this space space strategy game. its almost like old school turn base but its real time. so use pause alot when clicking on some things. reminds me of starcontrol and starcontrol two. But you can built a empire!


Ship design is for me the heart of the game, ship hulls are different for different civilizations. The fun part is how you use different components into the ship design to beat the other civilizations. since they have access to the same tech research as you. seeing your superior designs destroy them!! LIke a fleet of meat into your meatgrinder!

For example my favorite is the Kulrathi aka bearmen their ships might not be the fastest(not too many engine slots, you can put in different type of engines into that slot). but their fighter are the largest in the game. I love putting in fighter bays(they spawn fighters(free fighters)) into all my Titan ships(they are the largest hull type every civilization gets, each civilization has different sizes and shapes of that hull). I love putting in remnant shields onto the fighters and tons of weapons and no wrapdrive only thrust. They can be respawn from the carrier. Park the carrier slightly farther away from the fighting. wave after wave of fighters just destroy anything in their path.

With many patches later they fix the Remnant quest. Also remnant tech is always the most powerful in game. There are a few mods out there but the ones that still out there is fun.

reviewText:
Good game, IF, you like 4x strategy games. I am a fan of this game but there could be a lot more to it seeing how old it is. However for the time, effort, and abilities of Zerosum Games it is a good game. There are ups and downs to the game. (A lot of downs)
There are a few bad things about the game though. First there are some lag issues and stability problems. The game lags a bit when a lot of action is going on in a large galaxy. Second is mods. The whole game relies on mods at this stage to keep players interested and the game has a open mod folder to simply load one into. The website even comes with a tutorial on how to mod the game. Third is you have to be very meticulous to see what is going on when and where.
The game focuses more on combat than economy or events. The game has events but none have any significance or really game changing results whether that'd be good or bad. Events have changed over the year this game has officialy been out, that means a few events were removed, others added or tweeked. Economy is good but needs more to it as well. The game has two resources, food and production. Food is used to feed your race and production is used from building structures to ships. Other than that it doesnt get any more complicated. The only tricky thing about economies is taxing and distributing resources.
Combat offers a lot to the game seeing how that is the soul focus of gameplay. Ships can be custom designed with a traditional grid pattern and using moduels to fill them in. The possibilities are practicaly endless when it comes to combat.
Dev did abandon the game unfortunatly. After the full game came out updates have become rare. The game has absolutely no purpose but sort of sandbox game letting you do as you please. The only downside to that is there is no story to the game, no story or big explanation about the mysterious Remnant" race. All we get as far as story to any AI alien race is a short three sentence paragraph FROM the AI. And all we get for story behind the "remnant" is a short mini event quest that
recommended: gives literaly a short two paragraph explanation on them.\nThe game feels very open and at times too open. There needs to be more content before this becomes a real game because at this stage it does seem like a very high quality app than a full game."
hoursPlayed: April 27, 2014

reviewText:
So while i recommend this game it comes with a heavy stipulation:

If you are looking for a mediocre/easy but enjoyable 4xSpace Game with Decent to good Combat that doesn't rely on simple spam more ships. WIth a detailed fleet tactic editor. This is the game you're looking for

If you're looking for anything with diplomacy system deeper than Will you be my friend?" and any other victory conditions other than total domination. You're looking at the wrong game.

While the game is in general enjoyable often times i found myself wishing that the AI was more aggressive more defensive built up more force or somehow tried to oppose my dominance but those who are looking for something that really presents an interesting experience might be a bit dissapointed. You can taste the missed potential.

Enjoyable game Easy to pick up not as awesome as it could've been."

reviewText:
StarDrive gameplay takes place in real time. During skirmishes with opponents a player can take direct control of any unit subordinate to it, which greatly enlivens the battle. The creators also took care of the possibility of customization of weapons and equipment of each spacecraft. With the appropriate modules, each of the spacecraft can be adapted to specific tasks (for example,. Putting mines, shielding other units, transportation of raw materials).
The game is distinguished by aesthetic visuals. Attention is drawn primarily attractive views of space and animated feature films cutscenes.

As a minus I add - no optimization of the game. A few hours of play and the game sometimes freezes.

reviewText: I found the game to be quite enjoyable if a bit rough on the edges.  The one downfal is how essential your starting placement is.  Dont have enough early colony's available with some expansion planets in them you will have a severe disadvantage moving forward.  That said, the long game is just that, long.  Expect to dedicate time to keeping your fleet up to date and include it in your stratagey.  Multiple smaller fleets are the way to push ahead so one can be out expanding your empire while another is defending it while another is being refit.  All in all I do say a 60% is a deserving score, and not bad for a first game out.  While there are better 4X games out there, I dont feel I got shorted on what I payed.  Put more than enough hours in to justify the money.  Its a shame that he has to scrap the whole game to change direction, but making the move to turn based in the sequil will play better with the modular ship design.

reviewText:
Get this! It's that simple.  Okay first off I won't lie. I was worried about putting down 30 bucks for this game when I first came across it, even though I LOVE 4x space games. It's Metascore  is only a 61, but came across it during the Summer Sale and it was as low as 10 bucks.
So I went ahead and bought it.  LOVING IT!!!  It's how I wish Sins of a Solar Empire had played. Love everything about it. From building my own ships, to the races you can use, to how the map is random each and everytime.

I've heard it tends to crash on people, but I haven't had this happen yet. Are there bugs in the game? Sure. IS the dev working on them? Yes he is. Slowly but surely.

It's worth the 30 bucks, plus it give money to the guy who deserves it!

My score for this one is 8/10

reviewText:
It pains me to admit but I don't recommend this game.

I'm coming up 100 played on this game and I will probably play more as personally I enjoy playing StarDrive but I can not in good conscience recommend buy this title to even my vile enemies. Unless its on Sale, then it may be worth it if you enjoy this type of game. If I we're you however, right now considering buy StarDrive, I would spend my money of Galactic Civilation 3. It's the same game has this, in fact I would say this game is a bad copy of Gal Civ 2 which is a 'banging' game, although not as graphically nice as StarDrive gameplay is so much better. So if you can afford it Gal Civ 3. if you want to save money gal civ 2. Anything but StarDrive.

Right, so I've had a rant but objectively what wrong with the game. Weirdly not alot. It crashes for time to time normally because I'm tabbing out but autosaves stops that from been a big issue, and few minute roll back max is not really anything to get worked up over. The AI is bad, there are times that it seems slow and dumb, not even able to get off the starting planet. Other time as soon as they make contact they declare war and within 5 mins I have two invasion fleets heading to two different systems, this with the first 20mins of the game. I suppose you could agrue a degree of dynamic realism with the AI but it doesn't feel like that it just seems break. Hypo active somethings and hyper active other times never a good balance. The Gameplay is very long but that not really a fault of the game, more the genre. The tech tree is a bit bland as it's a standard tech tree discuss what race you play has.

In final conclusion; I enjoy playing the game, it has some nice features to it and a good about of variety when it come to ship design and weapons. However the game feels unfinished whenever I play Stardrive I have fun but i'm not satified and its for that reason I can't recommend it.

reviewText:
I came to StarDrive with a few hopes. I came after playing games like Sins of a Solar Empire, or Starwars Rebellion, or any number of other space tactics games...

I have see plenty that let you make your own ships, and others that have RTS and diplomacy inside them...
But its often not done well or very limited...

So far StarDrive does not dissapoint. Its simple and easy to start up and learn. (You'll really need those helpful videos ingame It WILL help...)
While it doesn't lead you around by the nose to teach you how to play the game, it doesn't really need to.


Once you learn what does what, you can be free to expand and play the game in any way you like. The interactions with the other civilizations also are great. They allow Rome Total War style deplomacy in getting trade...open boarders...tech....money...aliance and more.

But you can also so some more casual talk with them to learn about thier civilization, talk to them about other civilizations, and more as i am still learning the full options avalible to you.


The tech tree is a little complex and long winded...as there are about 7 differenct tech trees which make it hard to organize what you want to research first.
i Prefer the three tech tree system that has civilian. Military. Science.

They seem to break thier tech trees up into every kind of science....every kind of civil engeneering....every kind of military development...


But to the point.

Do i recommend this game? Yes!

If your like me then THIS is the game your looking for after playing Starwars Rebellion, and Empire at war. Sins of a Solar empire, and many others like it.

It fills my RP scratch, as well as my tactics and stratigy scratch and even my desire to build and design my own ships!

You wont regret it if you buy this game.

reviewText:
A nifty little game.

Sure its a little buggy, is missing many features and lags pretty bad during the endgame, but if we only focus on the negatives in life we end up like Hitler, or Cersei Lannister.

The good features far outweigh the bad, and I have had a brief addiction with this game. THE most fun thing to is obviously the ship design. In my experience, you can take the basic frieght ship from the start of the game, outfit it with nuclear reactors, and then crash them into the enemy. You can create ships, that spew out dozens of tiny fighter drones. You can create ships bristling with poisonous spores, and then bombard your helpless enemies ground forces. You can assume direct control over titan ships, driving them like Jesse Pinkman in the Need for Speed movie. You can launch an armada of mobile space marines that can board and control enemy ships. I could keep going for a long time.

Every piece of this game isn't just a statistic that somehow affects the game. If you research something, you will be able to see it, and use it. If you give some technology to another race, they will remember your kindness (even if they remember it as they are using that same technology to annihalate you).

Ive gone on for longer than i intended which just goes to show how much I like this game. In summary, StarDrive is an acquired taste. Like Dark Souls, coffee or Selena Gomez.

reviewText: I have played many 4X games, all of Master of Orion series, Endless Space and few others, so StarDrive was a must test. I liked the videos and screenshots, but actually playing it did not deliver. 15 minutes was all i could stand. The controls and UI are simply horrible. Buttons are small and spread wide across the screen borders. Font is plain and tiny, you can't scale them up. All the info is big masses of this tiny text, from which you need to gather information of what's happening, what means what. At the point i was simply trying to move camera around the galaxy, i quickly noted the developer hasn't learned anything about mouse controls from other games. Most of the general mouse functionality, such as simply dragging would have made it much better. Does he expect me to use arrow keys to navigate the map? But it was time to quit game before actually seeing any space combat, shame.

reviewText:
Space combat is exceptional due to the ship design and research systems. A must have for shipbuilders. And, it's real time strategy, no turns here.
Ground combat is terrible, I hope they leave it out of StarDrive 2 alltogether. It just gets in the way of space combat!

Diplomacy is straightforward; AI will either friend you, or declare war right off the bat. Makes things interesting. Although, the only way to win is to kill everyone. Even your friend, Mr. Treesong.

Racial graphics look very nice, sort of a high quality Flash display with artistic flair.
Space weapon effects are pretty good, especially the laser turrets. I always make sure to spam those. XD

I'm not sure why it's still priced at $30. Buy it on sale.

reviewText: This game is a great accomplishment, the developer is just one guy.  You won't find another game like this.   Find me another game where you punch through enemy shields and armor,  and then begin to damage internals effecting ships performance as ship modules are destroyed.  Knock out engines and the ships adrift.  Hit ammunition and you have a powder keg destroying half your ship or causing a chain reaction.  Destroy reactor lose power.  Have all your weapons shut down on one side because how you designed your ship when it takes damage.  My favorite is watching a ship spin off with destroyed engines or spin firing all weapons straight into the enemy flee.  This game is the next level of stategy and sets a new benchmark. I can forgive the few problems with the game.\n\nWhat are your alternatives?  The same old game,  do some damage and just simply down hitpoints until a ship explodes. I want to experience all of the above.  I think everyone posting negative reviews are just proffesional haters.  Maybe even other developers who are like,Uh-o if this game gets to big it will set the standard and we'll have to do allot more work.""

reviewText: A lot of broken development promises during beta, a serious lack of depth for a 4X such as pathetically stunted tech trees and gimmicky planetary micro-management, and lacking any charm outside of faction comm screens (Which, I must say, are at least pretty) make this a very deflated experience. Some basic UI expectations are not included (ability to delete save games for example).  Memory leaks prevent full use of title for larger maps or battles.  Minor  flavor aspects not complete and in some cases removed post the release date.

Developer has been abusive and tyrannical in controlling this information.  Existing content is mediocre even though concept is is good.

For additional uncensored information please visit.
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/SDVC/discussions

reviewText: This game is a great accomplishment, the developer is just one guy.  You won't find another game like this.   Find me another game where you punch through enemy shields and armor,  and then begin to damage internals effecting ships performance as ship modules are destroyed.  Knock out engines and the ships adrift.  Hit ammunition and you have a powder keg destroying half your ship or causing a chain reaction.  Destroy reactor lose power.  Have all your weapons shut down on one side because how you designed your ship when it takes damage.  My favorite is watching a ship spin off with destroyed engines or spin firing all weapons straight into the enemy flee.  This game is the next level of stategy and sets a new benchmark. I can forgive the few problems with the game.\n\nWhat are your alternatives?  The same old game,  do some damage and just simply down hitpoints until a ship explodes. I want to experience all of the above.  I think everyone posting negative reviews are just proffesional haters.  Maybe even other developers who are like,Uh-o if this game gets to big it will set the standard and we'll have to do allot more work.""

reviewText:
TL/DR: An average 4X game with a few charming features counterpointed by an overall feeling of an incomplete game.

I picked up StarDrive through a bundle pack and I admit that after about half an hour I metaphorically put the game back on the shelf for a couple of months before trying it again in earnest.

The learning curve is steep and the limited in-game help is definitely not intuitive, I wound up having the wiki and forums open on my second monitor and tabbing out to it every few minutes until I finally got the basics (about 8 hours and several games in).

The Ai is... childlike, it's incredibly easy to trick and throws a diplomatic tantrum at the drop of a hat. It felt like I was playing against a group of stroppy children (not helped by the Pollop race's dialog) and after a while it ceased being humerous and just became annoying.

The space combat is... interesting, the developers have obviously tried to use newtonian physics in the combat and it actually does feel quite good.... until your cruiser power-slides round a planet or your ships refuse to orbit a planet.

The ground combat is..... horrific, and not in an amusing way either. it's clunky and feels like a bad browser game interface.

The ship customisation though is a serious strong point for this game and for me it almost outweighs all the annoyances and the learning curve. I probably spent almost as much time in the shipyard over the past couple of days as I have actually playing the game.

The tech tree and progression is okay, though it's pretty obvious that half the tech concepts are inspired by, if not simply ripped from, the Star Trek universe. Polaron, phasor (yes, they just swapped an e for an o), disruptor etc.

In summary, if you get it with a bundle or you REALLY want to try it and it's a slow weekend then go for it. For all it's issues, I found the experience enjoyable overall... even if I probably won't be playing the game any more.

reviewText:
This game is obviously out of date, so my review is obviously too late as well. However, I've bought the game, and now played the game, and so I review the game.

It's too damned slow.

It takes hours to get your single-player, one-shot empire going, and then it takes even MORE hours to prosecute any wars you get into. The ships take a week and a half to turn around and most of the time they ignore orders or at least show no sign of receiving said orders. I'm forced to constantly click them towards any planet I want bombarded, and then they ignore anyway, and attack useless enemy ships that will affect NOTHING in the game. I just ended up CTRL-ALT-DELing the game to close it because it also takes hours to open and close. I'd delete it from the system, but that will probably take hours too, so I'll wait until I go to sleep to do that.

reviewText: I helped fund StarDrive's Development. When I first played the game, it was glitchy and lacking in AI complexity. The amount of enjoyment (frustration) I got from the amount of time invested just didn't make sense for me to continue playing the game in it's initial release form. So I shelfed it thinking that the Developer would finish the game via patches, add the content promised during funding, and make the game more enjoyable and stable. I came back about a year later to suffer the same errors and buggy gameplay I did on release. Now in 2016, several years after release, I find that the game only recieved updates for the first year or so: http://www.stardrivegame.com/forum/viewforum.php?f=9&sid=624bfa8276f66f0aa7b92e807eb641b3\n\nTo make matters worse - I now see the developer has made StarDrive 2. A game which almost certainly will be better than StarDrive, simply because the only thing complete about StarDrive was how complete a disappointment it was. I will not be patronizing this dev in the future. StarDrive 2 appears to have the same art, same AI, and same gameplay. Don't waste your time or money on either game.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game could be considered a diamond in the rough. Needs completing and polishing. Mostly the former. The game was abandoned in a beta state, incomplete and missing both basics and balancing. Then the developer had the gall to leave it unfinished and started up a sequel, which abandons the real-time for the turn-based (which seems less tactical in realism).

Of the 8 races, only 3 have customized solar systems (though one is Human, so really only 2 of 7 were done). The AI does not think long-term and the UI is very limited.

That said, the mods section leads to some very impressive mods, and has an excellent Star Trek mod on ModDB (recommend). Some of the mods make very simple changes, and other transform it (several fix the UI problem) into a completed, whole game.

While these mods are quite impressive, and I do recomend you try them in conjunction with this game, this game by itself is pitiful and incomplete enough to be considered a Beta.

reviewText:
It has good promise. It has good looks.

It unfortunately lacks polish.

The game is unfinished in many regards, but to me more than anything else is the balancing system within it. It just doesn't feel rounded out well enough to truly be considered finished. There are some bugs, glitches, and at times a good deal of rough edges to it. The gameplay is clunky, its approach leaves it too easy to overlook the time spent and the overal mechanics are hit and miss. That issue of the feel hits me in two regards, and the major one is how the empire grows and develops feels forced, and does it in a way that makes growth sluggish untill you hit a stage of performance where you just jump leaps and bounds. the staggering hiccup there just jarrs the whole gameplay on edge. It shows in combat if you don't hit the growth right before the AI does and you try combat.

Specifically the combat. systems designed to fulfil certain roles just don't. Many instances of the combat I am frustrated with how the AI will always outperform the player, and even on basic combat levels it shows to a starkingly annoying degree. The fleet system and ship controls on it sound good, but lacking that final polish to really make it a good system leaves much to be desired in combat - especially if you need to travel with ships capable of different speeds.

I like the lpooks, some of the mechanics are done well I think - but lacking that balance and refinement to really turn this into a good game.

If you want to see, wait for a good sale maybe, but I would argue just stay away.

reviewText:
Edit: Having played the game for more than a couple of hours, I see the game falling apart in my hands. Glitches, crashes, saves corrupting, it all sucks. The basic gameplay is fun, but the game is unfinished, as-in prelaunch. It's a beta, not a finished product. The developers have completely moved onto a sequel instead of finished the game they already produced, and the reviews I'm hearing for that game sound exactly like this review. User content patches do what they can, but they can't finish the game for the producers.

The overall gameplay is fun, if you can get past the awkward GUI.

Ship building is complicated and fun. Building and conquering is well balanced. I just can't get past the GUI.

Frankly, the GUI in this game is terrible, it's my number one complaint of this whole game. This is strange coming from the developers of Endless Space which has a perfect, smooth, awesome GUI.

What's wrong with the GUI you ask? Several things.
-Clicking on a button doesn't always" click it. It just doesn't respond... it just.... doesn't....
-Opening and closing the windows is awkward. The close button changes locations on every screen and disappears completely on others.
-They tried to integrate some UI stuff from Endless Space

reviewText:
This game is a lesson in bad management and bad design practice.

You simply do not promise features in a game if you cannot deliver them.  You can publish a list of features that you desire to add if possible, but you only promise the core elements.  And then once in production, you do not just abandon the project to start a new game, especially a sequel.  It is an unwritten contract between the dev and the buyer that you will deliver a working game with as few bug as possible.

As this game exists, the dev simply wasted to many development hours on a single feature.  The ship designing options in this game are hands down one of the best that I have seen.  You have so much control within the constraints put in place.  However, the whole purpose of a ship design is to utilize it in its function, typically combat.  And while combat is decent and some what fun, you need an economy to support it, and Stardrive simply does not have a well working economic model.

In fact, the game ends up punishing you for the 1st 30 min to hour of play.  1st by making you feel like you need to grind a bunch of base technologies just to be capable of performing the basic functions of a 4x game.  You will need new planets to expand you economic abilities, but you will feel you need 4 technologies before you can successfully colonize a planet: a food tech, a production tech, an income tech, and the ability to expand on to prohibited terrain.  However, if you focus on these techs to quickly start expanding, the AI comes and smacks you around because your military is weak.  So lets say you focus on military techs (like guided missiles and armor; yah, no armor before this tech), your units are capable of carrying a basic fight, but the AI has now colonized any half-decent planet on the map.  But then you say to yourself, I've got a big military I will just invade a weaker AI.  Welp, hope your like rebels suddenly poping up on your worlds with no prior indication of unrest because your income rate cannot support even a half decent fleet unless you colonize new worlds.  But wait you say, I'll just build a smaller but higher tech fleet; nope.  Not enough fire power to successfully invade a AI held world because unsuprisingly the AI has a fleet just as big if just a bit smaller but like 3x the troops you were able to build.  And all of this early game will determine whether you will win or loose late game.

However, this is not to say you cannot do well.  If you get lucky, the random map has placed habitable planets as neighboring systems, given you one of the less aggressive races as a neighbor, and not block those systems with hostile drones.  If you can survive this early game, the game can be a good bit of fun.  At least up until some late game bug or unfixed feature ends your fun.

A game should not punish players for trying to perform the tasks the game demands or make them slog through a list of Techs that can make or brake their game just to successfully perform those tasks.

reviewText:
I reccomend it only in that you will have a fun game if you can keep the enemy from getting remenant technology and forcing a wonder victory on you. This game has a modding scene and they can help you out with that problem. A real plus for me is that you can copy the game and stick it on a thumbdrive and it works without steam. So if anything you can buy this one for the ability to build an offline library for your computer games. Like say if you travel a lot or cannot afford a constant internet connection.

I don't think they patched this yet.

Though if you like strategy games and are looking for an offline game, go buy Planetary Annihilation from the Uber Entertainment store. Not from Steam, if you want an offline copy for yourself to enjoy with the ability to host a LAN party. Star Drive does not have multiplayer local or otherwise. I'm on the fence about reccomending this, buy at your own risk. You can still have a load of fun with it though, perhaps wait for a sale or get Star Drive 2 if you don't care about DRM.

Steam is DRM but it's only as restrictive as the developers want it to be, I do not know the DRM status of Star Drive 2.

reviewText: From the brief time of early access to the first release of the game, there was no new update, since then, it has only been minor tweaks, few and far between. Before early access, there was promises of a fully fleshed out experience. During early access, those promises remained. A few moments after first release, the dev stated that he will no longer be working on this game, so he may have time on his newer game which will be almost exactly like this game, only in a different engine, and hopefully better. He has also said that he plans to give all those who have bought StarDrive a discount on his next game, whenever it's released on Steam. Who knows how much of a discount that will be. Take a risk, buy this game discounted heavily in hopes that it will make the next game cheaper than the full priced original. Play this as the alpha that will never be finished. Don't buy this as a finished game, or even one that you expect future development on.
