reviewText: This game is a complete and infinite sandbox amalgamation of two of history's most prominant pioneers of deep space pioneer exploration game franchises; Master of Orion 1&2 and Star Control 1&2. If you aren't aware of these games or their significancant contributions to the genre than I simply could not even begin to lend any insight with mere words. On the other hand the game does feel... Unfinished. It has blockbuster potential for a niche crowd, and without keymapping within the game's options it does have a particularly cumbersome control scheme, which very well could turn away even the most enthusiastic of novice players. I also found myself strongly desiring far more depth of interaction dynamics between the various species. If you haven't any experience with this type of game, you almost assuredly will dislike this game. For me though, two thumbs up.

reviewText:
An absolute blast.

Stardrive is one of the many 'space-sims' currently on the market.
Expand. Research. Build. Conquer.

The same thing in all of them pretty much and i had alot of problems deciding wich one i'd settle with.
Sure. This one might not have the graphics but it has alot of gameplay value. I love it and it didnt take long before it became my favorite space-sim.
Mostly because of the sole fact that you can build your own spaceships. Decide what components goes where and strategically place the guns, engines, armor, fuel, batteries, sheilds, ammo, mass fabricators, wires, command modules... And the list goes on and on.
Research and always be one step ahead of the enemy in various fields. Wether you try to improve the economy and food production or expansion. Wether that'd be by force or settleing on uncharted worlds.


But building those capital-ships with onboard nukes. Boarding parties. Massive guns and fighter hangars? Wow. I love spending hours upon hours deciding the tiniest detail on my newest weapon of war.

8/10 for this type of game. Only thing missing is current-gen graphics.

reviewText: I wouldn't call this a 4X strategy, just a real-time strategy with a lot of depth. That's because there is no hard line between empire and battle, which I find a defining feature for 4X.\nRegardless of terminology, I find StarDrive to be a very enjoyable strategy. The shipdesign can be a bit overwhelming at first, especially on larger ships, but designs you make are forever and you can always modify them to adapt to new ideas. Front firing ships, broadside firing ships, you can do anything!

reviewText:
I bought this game 2 days ago and have played 14 hours of it, I still haven't finished my first game yet. The games are long but you are always kept busy between micro-managing each planet, and macro-managing your empire.

The interface is not very intuative and is slightly buggy, but with a little practice it seems rather simple.

The creating of your own unique ship's is a major part of the fun for me. Finding ways to optimize the standard ships is great fun, especially when a new teach finishes and a new strategy opens up.

Overall I would say this game is an excellent space 4X game with very unique race, each with their own personalities, a large variaty of ships, and the pleasure of dominating your opponants on a galactic scale.

reviewText:
I bought this game months ago and have played it after each patch release.  To date after 63 hours of play.... I still find it unplayable.   Those 63 hours compose many games that started off with promise but died out for one bug, balance issue, unfinished feature or another.  The core game shows great promise, but with debilitating bugs, and unfinshed content.

I had been waiting to write a reveiw though as patches were still coming and I was holding out hope.  Now the developer anounced they are done with this game and are working on a sequel.  The sequel will include all the things promised in the original game, I only need to pay again...  They did promise a 33% discount to current stardrive owners but that just feels like I have to pay 66% more for the game I tried to buy the first time.

So in summary BUYER beware of Stardrive and it's developer.

reviewText:
Do not buy Stardrive. This game is an unfinished product. It is, at best, “glitchy”. It's an “early access” with no chance of being fixed. Apparently, for reasons beyond the developer, he isn't allowed to work on the engine of the game any more, or something.

This is rather sad because the game needs optimization, badly. The controls and interface of the game aren't adequate. It makes an obtuse game with a steep learning curve even more convoluted. Basic RTS controls, like finding idle workers or rally points aren't implemented. At least one technology in the science tree doesn't work as described. Ships, especially freighters, lack a good path-finding, making them delay deliveries of vital goods, but it happens to offensive fleets too. Trading technologies requires you look up, -or know the cost by heart-, of everything in the science tree or risk the ire of the IA. The planet managing screen lacks clarity and the possibility for quick changes. The ship building interface refuses to show critical information, like the rate of fire, the global ammunition consumption per second or the global energy consumption. While it can be nice to figure out this puzzle, you have to recalculate everything as soon as you improve your design with new technologies. Having to look up the wiki for vital weapon-data is also unforgivable for a game that requires such precision in its main mechanic from the player. Personalising larger ship becomes a tedious chore.
Speaking of ship building, while it is nice to modify them depending on your style, it doesn't take into account how the game works as a whole. The IA isn't a big threat later on in the game as much as it is in the beginning, and that can be circumvented as soon as you realise what variable the computer uses for it's moves: the size of your fleet. Just build a big fleet, and you've won. You don't even need to research, or spend hours personalising cruisers. In the end, it is completely pointless, because you will already be winning by the time you get to bigger spacecrafts, making their puzzle-like personalisation moot and time wasting.
Worse, this system isn't as open as it pretends to be: you cannot build viable ships if you deviate from a certain type of fighter. If you are thinking of building a huge flying fortresses which shoots at everything in all directions, think again: one ship attacks one ship. Sure, the area of effect damage might hit others too, but that's leaving it up to chance, or worse, the IA. The attacks your ships employ are always the same: charge! There is an option to turn on a “broadside” tactic but it doesn't work according to the forums.
When you get right down to it, the changes you make to your ships are quantitative, not qualitative. You decide the weapons and the defences, and how much of each, and then try to figure out the best way to power the whole thing and keep sufficient ammunition. In essence, this more open system is just more complex than the one in Endless Space, replacing the straightforwardness of it with inconvenient and pointless creation tools. Also, Endless Space has more tactics during the combat phases, with three different phases, defining tactics for each, heroes and hero abilities. In Endless Space, the ships are not just flying towards each other like a Middle Age jousting competition.

It's a shame since Stardrive sounds good on paper. A better IA and path-finding across the board would have gone a long way. An IA that changes tactics depending on difficulty, rather than giving it a boring bonus to resources to compensate for it's inadequacies, would also give a more organic and challenging experience. Being able to annexe other civilizations peacefully by building a federation is great but removes diversity from the game world, by having the player taking control over the planets and fleets of the ally, making end game seem even more without challenge when you suddenly control half the map.

Finally, on a positive note, the aesthetic of the game, the design of the races and the ships, are very pleasing and enjoyable even thought there are basically references to other media (like the Wing Commander series, the mythos of Cthulhu, the Asari from Mass Effect, etc.). The mixture of all the references kind of creates its own style. The rest of the game though needed a lot more polish.

reviewText:
This game isnt great. After being released a while ago it still feels like an unfinished beta version of the game. Based on the forums, it doesnt look like the developer will ever finish the game because they've already started on thier next one. The game freezes, crashes, wierd buggyness, confusing as hell and is not polished in a lot of areas, but that all being said, its a lot of fun.
Think a much slower and less refined civ game based in space. I dont want to compare it to the other space games. I put it on easy mode, researched everything explored every nook and such and still didnt understand some of the mechanics. Then i built several massive dreadnaut class capital warships with intertial dampeners, filled one with nukes and another with the best shields and weapons money could buy and just walked through everything. That was fun. I really wish the devs would take the time to really finish this game, build in the tooltips and not make it impractical to research and such.
Ship building is awesome, its a bit much for me but if you really get into it, theres some crazy things you can do with it.
Resource management is like any other civ game. Its a bit quirky but theres some nice differences to set it apart from the rest.
The diplomacy stuff is meh, I was never good at dimplomacy but the 'tone' option you have on all responses really is a neat thing.
The slowness is a good and bad thing, sometimes a speed adjustment would be nice, but other times I couldnt hit the pause button quick enough.
Aside from any other unpolished based complaints, my big issue was with the notification system. My fleet could have gotten into a huge ambush or intercepted by the 'remnant' forces and I would have never known. It got me quite a bit of times and I'd never want it to be like civ which I think has notification overload but there needs to be more. I had a smaller map and its just too much to keep track of.

I dont know the cost of the game now, its definitely worth checking out, I only spent like 8 bucks on the sale so that was worth it, but dont expect it to be the next MoO and if you dont know what that is, then thats good, just go with it. I'll check it out six months from now and maybe I'll change my tone from 'threatening' to 'pleading' for forgiveness and like the wasteland 2 game I hope it happens, but this isnt even an early release. Good luck out there.
-Sincerely,
http://www.thecomic-community.com

reviewText: Well, I saw a lot of varying reviews, but the game was on sale and I gave it a shot. I've probably put in around 20-30 hours now, and I must say I find this game really addicting. The user interface takes a little time to get used to, but once you get the hang of it, the game's dynamics are pretty fun. The game is technically turn based in a sense, but turns are measured by time (every 5 seconds) which you can alter during gameplay, or even pause to get your orders out first, so the game is actually played as if all in realtime. In ship combat, you basically just tell your ships to attack the bad guys, so if you like to manuever fleets and such this game may not be for you. You manage just about everything for your species, which is pretty neat. And of course, you design your ships if you want. It may be time consuming, but is pretty fun. You choose a hull type, and then you are responsible for setting up the rest. Also, when you create a new ship, don't name it the same as ships you already have in play, because then you won't be able to refit your current ships. All in all, I would give this game an 8.5 out of 10. It is fun, and as you keep progressing, you can't help but to want to stick around and see what comes next. The graphics are fine, nothing super spectacular, but are still decent enough. I wouldn't pay 30 bucks for the game, but for 10, absolutely.

reviewText:
A quick summery if you dont want to read the rest of my review.
Yes the game does have its issues and I think it is really bad of the developer to release a clearly unfinished game and then to use the money they make of it to start on a sequel, yes this is really what has happened, but it is a good game. What is so frustrating that it wouldn’t take much to fix the issues, as far as I see them, and make it fantastic. Unfortuanly I have owned the game for several months and no update has come out and I don’t think one will unless no buys the sequel because of all the negative reviews of this one, which basically all say exact same thing.

This game really frustrates me. I like the idea and the game play. I really like the ship building element but due to the lack of different weapons it is a bit limited. The idea behind the remnant is very nice.
That’s the good part but now onto the bad.
For one it isn’t finish and if this is the finished game then there are some major issues with it. For starters even though every different spices has their own ship designs, which I like, they all use the same weapons and that irritates me. I know it makes it easier for stealing tech or giving it as a gift but to me it looks like a cop out.
The story line with the remnant is simply not finished. You build the finial building and suddenly you win and there is no explanation of what they were, where they came from and what happened to them that only powerful robotic ships are left.
The Ai is really predicable and irritating. You can be nice to one spices and get them to ally with you become your friend but if you make one trade proposal they don’t like you can lose all your trust with them in one go just like you weren’t even allies with them and you had just met. If you are allies with someone then that only means they won’t attack you, unless they revoke the alliance, but they will still try and steal you tech and have no consideration about the planets they take.
The game as so much potential and, before I realised that the developer had dropped it to work on a sequel, I was really looking forward to multiplayer to be introduced. I paid £25, ish I can’t remember the exact amount, for a game has been published and then not completed.  Having said that the game is good and I like it but after a while its problems have started to really annoy me and I for one won’t be buying the sequel until I know for sure the developers haven’t published and unfinished game again.

reviewText:
Just another disappointed early access purchaser. I sank a decent number of hours into this game but that was mainly because the pace of the game is slow, and after a while I ran out of new content ( wasn't worried though as I knew it was early access - my mistake ).

My advice, buy Stardrive2, it looks like how I assumed Stardrive1 was GOING to be before the developer(s) up and left it, abandoned. I'm just glad I got this game on sale 75% off, so I can't be too salty about it.

EDIT:

I have just played Stardrive 2
They changed the best parts of Stardrive completely, turns no longer play in real-time, the shipyard is worse - however they did add the ability to add upgrades to modules which I liked, the research system meant that you couldn't unlock every tech in the game without a silly race attribute, the space combat is slow and boring, ground combat is simple and the graphical 'improvements' make the game look weirdly cheap.

Bearing all this in mind...
My new advice, do NOT buy Stardrive 2 unless you want a more MOO3 type game, do buy Stardrive 1 - when it goes on sale - and mod it, with a community mod or something. I've had much more fun playing Stardrive 1 and that's just what I've came to accept.

I've changed my recommendation.

Buggy AI will keep those ships in-between systems forever unless you babysit them.  I'm excited to see a more polished version of this game in Stardrive 2.

reviewText:
I love this game so much. It still feels like it's in dev because there's still enough bugs and patches that are needed but it's still playable. Sadly the game feels like there is so much more potential yet it hasn't or will not tap into.

The game itself allows you to customize your own ships with a large variety of weapons, shields, armor, equipment, and whatnot. You can then make fleets of those ships and fight against other factions. The diplomacy in the game is better than what the civilization series has accomplished. You actually get rewarded quite well for being diplomatic instead of being completely warlike. Also the galaxy exploration is fun too. You can send out scouts looking for suitable planets for colonization and you can build your solar galaxy in between planets and can connect them with trade systems and territorial markers.

I would highly recommend this game if you love sci-fi space battles and the civilization series.
voteText: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Stardrive is like your normal 4X strategy, often slow to start up, but then builds it's stride.

Unlike other games, the combat is completely real time,  taking place on a top down view.  You are also giving different ship frames where you can customize how it is armored and armed square by square. It's an interesting thing, but this leads to a few problems.

Ship battles don't really have any sort of micromanagement, even smaller ships turn slowly. Ship AI is also lacking.  Also building new ship designs is also a timesink, especially when constantly researching new weapons.  This would be a huge problem in multiplayer.. which unfortunately there is none.

The game is still getting updates, but it's hard to justify a fullpricetag.

If it's on sale, it's is worth the time.

reviewText:
Well, wow... I spend a fair amount of time with this game, and have for some time... To see all the really harsh reviews suprises me a bit.

I've never noticed too many bugs frankly, certainly nothing that was a crash, or game killer.  Yes, the game does seem to have some unfinished bits here and there, but pretty minor stuff really. In my honest opinion it is one of the best 4x spacers available. What it really shines in is the ship construction. Once the tech tree starts to open up, the sky is the limit with what you can design your ships to do, though I generally end up doing the same strategies as some seem to be superior to others.

Perhaps the pricetag is a little high, but I certainly wouldn't discourage anyone from getting this game, I find it very enjoyable.

reviewText: I loved this game mainly because of the vast customization of ships. It did have some issues initially, but as updates have been released they have become increasingly less common. The technology tree was kinda small, but it was enough for me frankly because of the time it took to research the best things. Dynamic planets were also a cool positive that added some randomness to resource distribution throughout the galaxy. I do also know there are several mods out for this game that are free, but have never tried them. The main problem was with the game (imo) was the AI. They are not very intelligent and it can be really difficult beginning a new game because if you encounter a hostile race they will more than likely troop rush you and destroy you within 15 minutes. Lack of multiplayer was no big deal to me, but to some people I can see that as being a deal breaker.

reviewText: To be clear, I'll say up front that I very much enjoyed this game, played it for over 200 hours, and intend to snap up its sequel as soon as it's available.  What drew me to it the most is its innovative and thorough approach to ship design and combat.  If you'd enjoy spending 20 thought-filled  minutes crafting a customized inter-system war machine, this one's for you.  I should add that watching said war machine ply its trade is beautiful and enjoyable as well.  I loved almost everything about the design and implementation of the space combat in StarDrive.  Its real-time approach encompasses fighters, boarding parties, attack, defense, reinforcements, re-arming, repairing, bombarment, trade, support structures, warp speed and manuevering.\n\nHowever, I must also acknowledge that this game never overcame a certain lack of polish.  Confused AI, glitches, and underdeveloped or dead-ending side stories riddle the game.  In order to fully enjoy its excellent space combat system, you must learn how to work with the game's quirks and carefully guide the challenge level into an ideal range with practiced care.  I am amazed and impressed with what this game's creator(s) were able to accomplish.  At the same time, I can see why its metacritic score didn't make it to the 90s; its great strengths are forced to associate with a series of weaknesses.

reviewText:
Realtime 2D Space 4X.

Ship customisation is awesome, planet micro is not. The AI can handle a lot for you which is great (and a must). Ship/Fleet management is overwhelming and not very  necessary given Stardrive's game mechanics  - which is disappointing. Research tree is unnecessarily complicated (i.e. it is poor but not as bad as Sins of a Solar Empire).

Did you understand all the jargon and enjoy MoO2? - then this is your game. Endless Space is better than Stardrive in all aspects but Endless Space has a completely different ship combat mechanic and is turn-based. If combat is the make or break choice: choose Stardive if you want to control swarms of 2d ships, choose Endless space for battle strategy and awesome combat visuals.

Get it only on sale.

reviewText: While this is a great game worth a look, a ball was dropped somewhere that makes you feel like you bought half a game.    You can assume manual control over your flagship" but this is sort of useless; I find myself never making use of the ability.  That
date: coupled with the fact that there's a game type selector but no game type except the default
recommended: tells me that this game started with the intent to develop something akin to StarFlight or Star Control II
hoursPlayed: but that inability to manage scope led it to becoming just another Sins of a Solar Empire clone.\n\nThat said
voteText: the AI is challenging
helpfulPercent: though it tends to make odd choices at times.   Unfortunately
votesHelpful: the races are very predictable in behavior
votesTotal: and seem a bit like ripoffs themselves.   The Kulrathi warrior bear race reminds me a little much of the Kilrathi warrior cat race from old Wing Commander.   There's a race of squid-beings that have ships and philosophy very similar to the Reapers from Mass Effect.\n\nI did enjoy playing this game for one or two playthroughs
votesFunny: and the modification of the ships is an interesting mechanic
commentsCount: but I found myself going back to Sins of a Solar Empire to get this sort of fix.   Between the lack of creativity on the alien races and the clear false-start of creating an "adventure" mode
column16: I was never able to shake the feeling that the game was completed halfway and the rest was just phoned in.   It's a game worth playing if you can grab it on Steam Sale
column17: but it's also a lesson in how scope creep can turn a great idea into an unfinished project."

reviewText:
Game is absolutely tons of fun, when I first got it I racked up the hours bloody quick, good thing I was on holidays.

I'm a huge fan of space basd strategy games and usually go for 4x turn based ones. I purchased this on a whim. Its all real time and done from a top down perspective, which I found unepexted and, at first unapealing. However, as I learned my way around the contrls and began combat, I realised how much fun this game can seriously get. The combat in this is tons and tons of fun, least of all because of the creative control you have on your ships. You get the blueprint of your ship, and then fill its insides with weapons, power, bridges, the lot. You then test your design out in combat. It has great visuals and beautiful weapon effects, all the races ships feel different and look cool. Its only downside is Empire building and the economy is pretty shallow. Buildings are generic and colonisation is always the same.
The planets serve only as the economic base for your fleets, which you will be building enmasse

reviewText:
It's been very difficult for me to get into 4x games. I tried Galactic civ 2 a little while ago and got confused as anything, tried to play a bit of Sins of a solar empire but was completely overwhelmed with how much was involved in playing. Then I picked up Endless space, which I'm really wanting to get into but the learning curve again is huge for me.
The only 4x I've enjoyed and have found easy to play but not spent a great deal of time on is Civ 5, which I plan on going back to sometime but for some reason I'm set on learning how to play a SPACE 4x.

With Stardrive, I think I've found my 4x space training wheels. I've not found it as complex as the others, not turn based and for me, it's easing me into how 4x games essentially work.

I can't say much about the negativity surrounding the game because I'm only new to the genre but as a game, I'm finding that it functions great so far.

Graphically I can not complain, the music and sounds are nice. I'm sure as I play more, I'm going to find things I don't like and once I get used to the genre I'll start playing other 4x space games then look back on this and make comparisons but for now, this seems like a great entry level game to the genre.

reviewText:
Played this game in Beta and was really excited.  4X space rts with potential to be best of the era.

Unless you're running this game on D-Wave One (google it) this game WILL be slow by the times you reach a good point in the tech tree.
My PC is still pretty high spec and struggles to run it on anything past 1280x1024 resolution.

The game is also littered with bugs, crashes frequently, and doesn't scale to monitor size properly.

Would love to recommend this game if it was finished as it is such a good idea, and such a great presentation, but at the moment all I can say is I want a refund.

reviewText:
I'm somewhat on the fence about this game, but I think I can say I recommend it with reservations.

The real-time approach is often a mistake in making a 4X game; StarDrive manages to avoid most of the big problems that other recent attempts (most notably the terribly disappointing Armada 2526) have had. The mechanics make sense, and the player can make informed choices to wring out advantages to actually win battles, wars, and the game. Custom ship designs are a key part of the value proposition of the game, and the implementation here is meaty and satisfying.

Those good things said, the game has some big flaws in usability/playability. There is often only one way to perform an action  (scrap/refit a ship, scroll the map) when there should be several; information displays like the known-planets list and ships list are missing key features. Also, while the ship design module is a lot of fun early in the tech tree, as ships get larger the lack of any automated support makes filling in all the boxes of a design tedious instead of fun.

I picked StarDrive up as part of the holiday sale, and I can say it was worth the discounted price to me, but I'm not sure it would be worth full price.

reviewText:
I see a lot of negative reviews for this game and I really don't agree with them. This is a solid game with a very distinct art style. It looks really good and yet very simple, which is not a bad thing. The game is very easy to learn and is quite deep in it's ship customization and you will spend many hours designing and perfecting your ship designs. There is nothing more satisfying than having your custom badass capitalship send out a swarm of your custom fighters and totaly anhialate an enemy fleet.

Compared to a lot of other 4X games, Stardrive does not have as big of a techtree, there is still plenty of things to research but compared to games like Endless Space it's far from enough. One thing I really miss is more ways to improve your planets and concidering all the buildingspace you have left, there is room for a lot more.

Pros:
- Short learning curve
- Deep shipdesign
- Real-time gameplay
- Addicting

Cons:
- Not enough to research
- Ground battles
- Game crash after a few hours of play
- Save files are way to big

reviewText:
I've decided to re-write this review as I feel I can offer a better oppinion at this point.

Right out the bag, this game is, in many ways absolutly incredible. The scale, depth and presentation is wonderful. The developer has managed to achive something amazing given both that this is his first game and that he's working solo.

The early game is wonderful, the ship designer is interesting, there's a good variety of planets, anomalies and the races all look brillient.

But, and it is a bit but, this game is also rather tragic. The potential it has was vast, and while some of it has been lived up to, due to poor engine choices and the dev choosing to remake the game in unity and create a sequal, the game is unlikely to get any better. Preformance is buggy, especialy later on. Late game is dull and will have you either compleatly dominate or be wiped out in the early game. Lack of multipalyer limits the games's life time signifigantly, and things such as the half finnished remnets plotline just make me want to cry.

That said, despite all it's faults I've still put in around 60 hours at time of writing, from multiple playthoughts, meaning that the cost per hour is less then 50p.

While the games has it's moments, the problems coupled with the fact that a remake and a sequal is arriving soon makes me recomend that you don't buy unless your fine with a incompleat, thought still impressive experiance. Wait till the sequal.

reviewText:
Do you like good ideas?

Are you the kind of person who enjoys planning, resource management, and conquest?

Will you pay a developer for the privledge of being a beta tester?

Then you'll love Stardrive!

With a non-existent story, turtorial, or multiplayer mode, this game is a bargain.
Stardrive will immerse you in a universe with no objectives of any kind.
A game is great when it can drop you into play and never explain core gameplay or controls!
When your framerate drops to 2 when you scroll out and check the map you know you've got a winner in your hands.
If you have any problems with bugs, crashes, or deleted saves, you can be sure that your issue will be heard and never resolved!
Stardrive is a stellar example of the best that a Kickstarter funded, early access project can provide.

Do you like buyer's remorse?
Then pick up Stardrive for the low price of $32.99 today!

Don't buy the game, it has a few nice parts, but it's essentially an abandoned game that never left alpha.

reviewText:
Runs at last, but...
No this game actually isn't bad. It's rather quite fine, but sadly also buggy. Some issues make it crash during diplomacy, others during deploying ground troops, and I also encountered a crash as I colonized a world.

The game looks neat, as far as it runs, it's of course not as polished as it could be, but there are already a lot of options. Sadly there is no more official support to this by the developer, but the fans still try to update it on a regular basis.

Pros:Collection of several races, that can even further be tweaked with traits.The player decides the size, and resources of the galaxy or sector. Systems can have a good variety of planets.
Cons:The game is buggy and crashing regulary, safe often.Not well supported by the developer, because the second part is out already.
Not recommended for everyone
The game is nice, sadly it's both no longer supported by the devs and it's buggy and crashy. But there still is hope, there is an inofficial patch for the game, that gets updated on a regular basis, and alone those Fanbase make the game still a good game. But, you have to know the basics of modding, and you have to keep in mind that the game still isn't running as smoothly as it should.

Given the issues with the bugs, crashes and lacking support, the positive things about the game are you can play it, though you will have to install and upkeep the patch. I encountered several problems during the first three or four tryouts, it's unclear why - because the final patching worked perfectly fine and I did nothing different.

If you are fan of the 4x Space Exploration genre, this game might be for you. Especially if you aren't afraid to mod your games and give it a try. But if you are inexperienced with modding, have problems with finetuning your software or system, then this game might be not for you - it will try out your patience and may pull the strings of your nerves.Don't buy the game when you want a fast, and relaxing playing experience.

reviewText:
Here we are, months after purchase and hours into the game.

So much potential, squandered, wasted.

ZeroSum games was basically a one-man studio, with what seemed like a desire to bring back a great space-4X in the vein of games like Masters of Orion.  Oh, the disappointment.

It started great.  Bought this on early access, it had some problems, a couple major ones in fact, but it was close enough that you could see the point of it all, even then, and could see the few hops and leaps it'd take to get the foundations in place and really start cranking out an awesome game.

Instead, what we got were sweet nothings and empty promises from ZeroSum, tales of how we would get X Y and Z features or fixes.  Trade is still broken, warping still doesn't work properly, warp nodes and defensive emplacements are still prohibitively expensive, the AI is still crap and consistently allows itself to get rolled over in stupid and meaningless ways, often outright killing themselves due to what should be only one or two MINOR circumstances regarding their worlds and infrastructure...  No balance, no design, no polish, the damn game isn't even finished.

ZeroSum took a game, created a clear image, started tapping serious potential...  And then turned around and flipped their entire customer-base for this game the bird.  Zero literally said he would fix the problems and get the game working...  After saying this, he never even got around to the first major gameplay problem, the broken Freighters...  And then announced StarDrive 2.

Do not buy this game, do not support ZeroSum games, do not support Iceberg Interactive until they drop ZeroSum, because at the very least, ZeroSum Games is nothing more than a shady, cash-grab studio who does not deserve to be called a Games Developer, and Iceberg deserves to same insults and utter lack of respect for as long as they intend on keeping such a disingenuous, malicious individual/studio under their umbrella.

StarDrive is a game to AVOID AT ALL COSTS.

reviewText:
Warning - this is long

I found Stardrive ages ago and saw a lot of good things about it.  It was in alpha/beta though and Steam was nice enough to point me at the products webpage, because as handy as steam is they cant list all of a products features on their little webpage (I dont think it had the read more tabs at the time).  Looking at the developers product page and seeing youtube videos of what you are going to purchase is just good consumer behavior so that you know what you are purchasing.   It looked really interesting and offered things such as

Moo2 like but RTS 4x
Multiplayer
Create your own fleet designs
Special Missions in which you assume control of an individual ship instead of a whole side
A sandbox mode with an engaging storyline.
Neutral factions like remeneant and pirates
A variety of random Galaxy events.

Shortly after buying in the developer said he was temporarly removing multiplayer to work out the kinks. Of course the sandbox storymode wasnt finished yet but thats ok it was in beta and we saw how it was going to work with researching technologys and contacting a neutral planet and yadda yadda.  And watching the WTF is, along with other videos I knew what to expect with late game latency, so when people bashed on it I spoke up for it, telling people to give it time.  As a one person developer a 1-2 year wait for him to fix things up was acceptable.  Especialy for a game that had already been in development for something like 4 years.  But it was nearly done,  so we should hold on before making judgements.  I made guides, tried to help people out,and gave suggestions.

But the longer it went on the more sour it got.  A couple weeks out of its -short- Beta when we could no longer get refunds there was a 50% off sale.  A couple months after that we were told Multiplayer would never make it to the game and that maybe in a stardrive 2 we would get it.   Special missions were abandoned all together.  The Galaxy events were restricted to simple planatary shifts for fertility/richness.  The Remenent story-arc was removed (and then later reintroduced in a shoddy manner).  Some of the AI's were just left in a crippeled state.   And then afterall of that there was a Fertility/abundance nerf across all difficultes (that the AI ignores) that you cant disable... Why nerf fertility/abund in a single player game?  A -lot- of players got banned from the message boards for silly things and it was a pretty rage induceing time all around.

But thats ok I thought,  I decided to give him more time.  He said development would 'slow' while stardrive 2 was in development but we could expect improvements.  I decided to wait for SD2 to get finished before looking back and seeing what has changed.

So this last week I gave it a try again.  And I have to say i am not very happy with it.  I enjoyed the game more during beta and after 'release' with the late game slowdown then I do now.  Sure some small bugs were fixed with fire arcs and its a little bit smoother.  But several AI's just sit there and let other AI's conquer them with out putting up a fight, several races just refuse diplomacy of any sort (usualy the ones that are conquering other ai's),  and the AI still cheats up the wazzoo building fleets it cant possibly support.  And overall it feels really bad fighting over a 4 population planet with a 1.2 fertility and 1.1 richness because thats the best there is out there.

In the end the game currently (may 2015) feels unfinished (even more so then during beta), and in need of a good AI patch, a balance patch, a few new galaxy option sliders to combat what was done post release, and maybe a gamemode paid DLC.

I'm gratefull for the 33% discount on SD2 for SD1 owners,  its a nice gesture.  And I really do hope SD2 turns out well, and can compete with other games in the turn based strat genre. But in the end this game also made me deicde to hold off on SD2 until its cheep as dirt.. because no matter how good it looks 'now'  it could be a lot worse in 6 months.   And thats just not something I ever really expected to say about a game.


ps- yes I know my spelling sucks. Hopefully it wasnt too bad.

reviewText:
It does not matter what anyone else tells you: this game is not finished and has been abandoned by the developer. It will never be finished nor its bugs fixed. Some of these bugs are game-breaking and there are many features that are either incomplete (to name but one: game mode. You can choose it when you start a new game, you get to choose only one option, though -_-) or inexistant.

Now to the game itself, it is an ok game that appears to be a rip-off of a lot of games, but the ship designer as well as space battles are genuinely fun. I would almost call the initial ships being crappy a stroke of genius since it gives you a nice challenge to build good ships for each faction and possible tech configurations etcetera, this part is really fun. The automation of building them is ok, and putting them in fleets is very nicely done with the fleets manager.

The gameplay itself, not so much. You initially start with one planet, and the one whom colonizes the most suitable planets the first is generally the first to win. If your race has improved metabolism that is every planet with 0.8+ fertility. Mind you those planets tend to be rare (10-15% of all colonizable planets I think?), which only makes it worse that you can also choose to make your race cybernetic. Combine that with industrious and improved metabolism and suddenly your requirements have changed to all planets with 0.8+ production instead (assuming 20-25% tax rate). This basically means 75% of all colonizable planets, most of them being uninteresting to other races except the Opteris (cybernetic), mainly for this reason, that race can actually pose a challenge in the hands of the ai.
Granted, you can research stuff to make all planets viable for colonization or bother with crappy food transportation, but that goes against colonizing fast.

So combat: by default, you are at peace with every race. If you have troops/fleets in orbit of each of their planets cabable of annihilating them in a few seconds they will not care. If they intercept one spy they are likely to declare war, but with war you get space battles! Still, if you choose the best possible strategy, there will be no space battles: as long as your military strength is higher than your opponents', only the Opteris will ever dare attack you. And even when it is not, half the ai players will generally just seek peaceful relations (pacifist/cunning/honourable ais). There are also planetary battles: capturing planets through troops. Troops cost no maintenance, though, so flooding each of your planets with troops is a sure way to win: the ai will never bomb your planets.

Remember the game-breaking bugs? One of them involves unlimited production! It involves having shipyard, you spend 10 spare production on a ship, get 13 invested, cancel it, and now you have 13 spare! The shipyard effect even stacks with multiple shipyards, so I don't think I need to tell you how horrible it is to leave this bug in the game.

Overall I give this game a 4.0/10
Kicking dumb ai asses does make me feel better, but you are better off with something like Distant Worlds.

reviewText:
I cannot say I would recommend this game, mainly because of the promises broken. Primarily the promise for multiplayer, Other than that area the game was a good spiritual successor to Masters of Orion 2, I won't lie and say it had amazing diplomacy, mainly because it didn't. But I loved the ability to design my ships and it did well on that, It does or did have a collision issue with ships ramming into your ship through armor and shilds and doing internal damage, but to be honest not doing a proper build of your ship is the end cause of the failure.  I would definitely not pay the full price, and I wouldn't belive anything this developer says at this point, but the game was fun by itself, would have been amazing if it actually had multiplayer as promised.

reviewText:
STARDRIVE.

The little 4X that almost could..


For starters, i must voice my bias. Towards grand-stategy and 4X-Games. They have been my personal guilty pleasure for the longest time. However, even with the enjoyment i get from them. There are examples of the genre that are not exactly the best and unfortunately StarDrive falls to that category.


This is easily explained, the game is dull. Bloody dull...  In all of my 140+ Hours of playing it, i have completed it only thrice.
And every time, the end-game played out the same. Every single time, not counting the time i went all Borg with the Opteris. This is mainly due to design issues with the Tech- political- and AI-systems, they feel unfinished and in many ways they still are. The game still crashes now-and-again and some of the mods that have been made for the game only make it even more unstable. (This just might be only on my end, but its still a noteworthy issue.)

And for a game that is aesthetically very similiar to the good old Master of Orion series, the problems only make it worse. Since in its core, the game is broken and even with the patching the developer has done (and if memory serves it was just one guy.) the game is still broken.

And i'm really sad about it, since the idea is so good. A spiritual successor to Master of Orion, with better graphics, sound and all the other fluff. StarDrive tries to be that game and in some ways it has succeeded, but the technical and design issues are the things that kill the experience, not to mention the pacing.

In all, StarDrive is a decent game. Even with all of its obvious problems, it is somewhat enjoyable. But not by much. It gets dull really fast and with the pacing being off, i really doubt that you could squeeze more than few playthroughs out of it. And even the modular ship building system, can only squeeze so much fun out of it.

StarDrive.

I think a C , is the best grade i can settle for. This coming from the game being still mostly incompleted and the modding only helps so much. But to give a yes or no on the recommendation option, i think i still need to put a yes on it. Since Steam has no neutral"-option in the recommendation thing..

Furthermore
date: i would not recommend paying full price
recommended: buy this when it goes on sale. Since the content isnt there for 30€ (or regional equivelant.)."

reviewText:
So i sunk about 20 hours into this game comparing it other games in the turn based/semi realtime space expanding empire genres. A genre i really enjoy.

At first I thought the game mechanic and themes could be good and was enticed by the ability to find, explore and colonize new worlds.

I was impressed by the level of scripted automation and the feel of some of the game.

Unfortunately for me it fell short on the gameplay side of things and many aspects seemed to be very similar to other games of its genre.

Unfortunately I did not reach the compelling and addictive gameplay I was looking for andI think some areas were on the right track but did not quite make it to the punch the developers were potentially looking for.

Dont give up just yet, maybe a followthrough on the detail and gameplay in the sequel?

3.5/10 . frustrating once you finally get a handle on things. Sorry.

reviewText:
StarDrive is one of those games that looked good and innovative when it was in development, but ultimately fell short of expectations once it was released. The game was released fairly quickly - some would say a bit too quickly - and while it did receive several significant patches and updates after release, the post-launch development was not nearly as comprehensive as the community, in my opinion, deserved. As of the writing of this review, ZeroSum Games has already announced that they are making a sequel. Maybe it's just the cynic in me, but it seems as though this first game was really little more than a test run designed to iron things out and bilk some folks out of the money that the studio decided they needed to create the 'real' game. I can only hope that this sequel does more to address the issues that StarDrive had and provides a more satisfying 4x experience.

Even at the supposed 'end' of its relatively short development cycle, the game still suffers from a number of glitches and bugs, as well as incomplete or poorly-executed gameplay systems. Ships and fleets often suffer from poor pathfinding and an inability to carry out simple orders. Up until the last update, the few 'random events' that made up the in-game 'storyline' were still incomplete or did not work properly. The lack of any sort of scaleable engine technology or range limitations on your ships pretty much allows any player to scout out the entire map in the blink of an eye, destroying any sense of gradual exploration and leaving you susceptible to zerg rushes from any 'warmonger' races you have the misfortune of rolling up a new game map alongside.

Planet development, research, and economics are serviceable but pretty bare-bones. The short tech tree is ridiculously easy to blow through with 'standard' pacing, and really needed to be at least 50% larger than what it was; several branches were seriously underdeveloped. Terraforming is almost nonexistent and the greatest variety of planet facilities is in defenses; there are no more than two or three facilities each for farming, industry, and research. The economic system had the potential to be quite intricate with its system of freighters physically transporting goods between planets; however, the limit of only three resources (food, industry, people) and the seeming lack of promised effects from the economic-related techs don't contribute to a realistic economic model and make it hard to afford much infrastructure.

Game setup doesn't provide a lot of options compared to other 4x games (Endless Space, GalCiv 2, and MoO2 - which this game purports to be emulative of - come to mind). Even the largest map size doesn't seem to be quite big enough, particularly given how sparse most star systems are and how many turn out to be crap - which, given the lousy terraforming options, make meaningful expansion of your empire difficult. Locations such as volcanic and ice worlds, gas giants, and asteroid belts, rather than providing additional options, are instead little more than eye candy, contributing nothing of value to the overall game when they could've added whole new dimensions to the tech tree and gameplay.

The game's seven races are fairly original, for the most part - conforming to the usual tropes, but distinctive in their own ways, though some are considerably more derivative than others. The diplomatic options are good, if not outstanding, and  the responses provided in the course of shooting the breeze with a particular species are amusing, while providing a gist of each race's personality and culture - though there's not a great deal of background information to be gleaned during the course of gameplay. The diplomacy system gives you an idea of how a given species feels about you, but no feedback on what you can do to improve relations. Espionage provides a number of options for stealing or sabotage in a fairly good, time-duration assignment system that relies on hiring spies and advancing them in rank.

I do have to say that the game's ship design system is solid, allowing you to get down into the nitty-gritty of customizing each vessel to the last component. Everything comes down to power; each component has to be within range of a reactor or power conduit or it won't function. Design a ship with too many power-hungry systems but not enough power generators, and systems will shut down once its reserves run dry. Ship-to-ship combat happens in real time on the system maps (a la Sins of a Solar Empire) and hit detection and damage is location-based, with external systems taking damage first before the guts of the ship can be hit.

What this means is that ship design must be well thought-out and involves compromise. With only so many slots on a particular hull - and only so many internal and external slots available - you have to strike a balance between power systems, weapons, and defenses. Ships with heavy armor on the outer edges will have less space available for weapons ports; shield generators have limited coverage bubbles and must be positioned to protect the whole ship; reactors are volatile and will cause splash damage to surrounding components if they are destroyed - do you have the space to spare for internal bulkheads, or do you trust your ship's armor and shielding? Each weapon can be given an individual arc, allowing you to construct aggressive, maneuverable, front-heavy gunfighters or well-defended, multi-turreted line warships capable of massive broadsides - or anything in between. All that's needed is a way to lock each weapon in position so it can't be moved - errant clicks while upgrading or changing designs can skew a turret's alignment clear out of whack, which can lead to whole fleets with frakked up aim if you happen to not notice.

StarDrive does have some good points and interesting design features, but overall the game feels incomplete. I could go on about other aspects of the game that suffered from clunky design or thin or incomplete treatments, but the message has been stated - StarDrive is not worth picking up, at least not at this point. Clearly it has been popular enough to warrant a sequel, and hopefully the developer will take the time to get things right in the second game. StarDrive 2 definitely needs a far greater level of depth and sophistication in its gameplay if it wants to stand out from its competition in this fairly crowded field of space empire-building games, and needs to have the glitchy systems and underdeveloped features of its predecessor ironed out in order to deliver a satisfying experience. Hopefully the sequel will prove to be a game that greatly improves on its 'trial run' predecessor and is able to succeed because it is well-designed and provides deep gameplay options - something that the original game has not succeeded in delivering.

recommended:
unfinished mess is now being touted as a complete game.

As for the specific issues with the game:

PROS-

1. It is a 4X game played in real time. That allows for a number of new strategies not possible in the ordinarily turn-based genre.

2. Stardrive brought something new to the 4X table with the ability to design/fit your ships from scratch. This was the core pulling factor of the game. With customizable ships
hoursPlayed:
you could choose from a pre-existing hull and redesign the ship to suit whatever specialised need. Titanic capital ships dedicated to bombing a planet into a foetid hellhole (i.e. conducting Exterminatus)? Done. Beam cannons on a fighter? No problemo. Or how about a logistics ship to provide repairs to your fleet on the go? All possible.

CONS-

1. The Sunburn engine is a laggy unoptimized mess. The framerate basically commits suicide during mid to late game

reviewText: I brought this 4x game a while back and was full of promise for what it had the potential to become, back then the developer was promising all sorts of intresting features in the form of updates and frankly they have not turned up in the quanity they should have. Now thats not saying this is a bad game, the ship customization and planet management is excelent and the combat feels like it should in space, but it just can't carry the game on there own. Wheres the Multiplayer? Story mode? Improved diplomacy? We were promised it but it just never materialized. Its a trend thats been happening for the last year with 'pay to play early' Alphas and Betas, and i honestly wouldnt of minded if the game had been continualy updated and polished. But it wasn't, It's AI feels buggy and will uterlly crush you on anything higer than Normal, balancing resource production is a NIGHTMARE, the game crashes after several hours play for no reason and Diplomacy isnt finished, just the classic 'give me tech and planets' approch or picking from a list of things your spys can do. The term 'cash grab' certainly has come to mind.\n\nIf somebody put another 6 months into polishing and actualy finishing this game it would be great, in its state now? Save your cash, go play Galactic Civilization II, SIns of a Solar Empire or Armada, that should cure your itch for space colonization for awhile.

reviewText:
Game is too easy for classic grand strategy (4X) genre in every aspect. You can learn all the tricks in mere minutes and there's not much to do after that.
Most annoying is the tech tree: it is just too shallow and all-visible at start (well, there's something like 1-6 upgrades in 1-3 tech trees in each of five tiers plus one 'hidden' tier). Upgrades are completely evolutional, improving just main characteristic of shield/armor/weapon/etc.
Space combat is really nasty too: no matter how much time you spend designing your ships combat result is mostly determined by ability to sustain DPS and hit the target (like a not-so-large pack of cheapest fighters with ammo-less lasers easily destroy something like cruiser). Moreover ships in fleet do not keep formation during combat thus there's no such thing concentrated fire or support ships staying in safe position delivering ammo/repairs to the hot zone.
As for diplomacy, well there's none out there. First Civilization had as much diplomatic choices as we have here and it is not the simplicity you want.

To be honest there's a couple of things that are good: it is ship designer (however you cannot fit your design with latest weapons/armors just developed by your techs, you need to do it manually) and 'turnless' strategic mode, however there're many space strategies which include these pros and doesn't have so much cons. If you want a good game, go for endless space (easy to learn) or something like space empires V or distant worlds (much harder thingies)

reviewText: This game was good at first, when i believed it was incomplete and still a work in progress, so much potential... Sadly, that went unfulfilled. The game seems to not want to communicate very well, with scant notifications or pop-up messages telling you whats afoot in your empire. The diplomacy is pretty light, though not the worst in the world. But for a game about ship combat, there's a surprisingly small amount of control, as aluded to earlier, you get no notifications when your ships are in combat, nor can you zoom to your ships or padlock ther camera on a ship (only your flagship and any ship you manually take control of) which makes the game seem incomplete. So many features seem unfinished or rushed and there's no word from the DEV on fixes or further development. The game looks exactly like Distant Worlds and attempts to play very similar but is a far inferior product and I'd reccomend that game over this any day, on account of it being a complete and enjoyable product, unlike StarDrive.

reviewText:
I'll be up front right now, I like this game. It offers a unique experience and I find myself coming back again and again to play it. That being said I would not reccomend it unless it was on at least a 75% sale as the game is not complete and pretty much never will be because the dev dropped it.

Now you can play the game, isn't broken you can play and finish a scenario but this game was abandonned and a lot of promises that were made were broken by the dev so there is lack of content and after a few games you get the gist of how things will go and the prospect of losing goes out the window even on the hardest difficulty. The Blackbox mod can fix this a bit but overall it's a problem. In addition you will suffer a lot late game due to poor optimisation that even a really powerful system can't power through. I put a lot of time into this game on my 3570k which was overclocked to 4.8Ghz and on the larger universe settings I still had significant slowdowns and juttering which can and will render the zoomed in direct fleet control unplayable. It basically leads to you sending massed fleets into enemy held systems and hoping that the AI can take care of things.

The best thing to do is the leave the universe size to normal and use the Blackbox mod to limit the number of ships the AI can have because if you don't you will quickly find that the AI will continue to pump out droves of ships and each one will make the game run a bit worse after a certain point. That being said if you have a recent Intel based chip(Sandy or newer) your system should easily be able to handle around around a thousand ships in the universe without significant slowdowns.

Probably my favorite thing about the game is the ship customization. In a word it's friggin cool and it really makes you feel good when your ship you designed is good enough to take on three or four ships of an equivalent class of ship and come out on top. That is I think the thing that really keeps me coming back because I keep finding better and better ways to build my ships and it feels really engaging.

To wrap up this game had loads of potential but it was let down by poor choices made by the dev in both the way they made the game and how the handled the abandonment of it. It is in no way worth the standard $30 asking price, you can pick it up for the unique experience but only if it's less than $10.

reviewText:
OK this is getting long so don't buy this game. It's buggy and shallow with few saving graces. After 57 hours of gameplay I can say without a doubt it was not worth the $7.50 I paid for it.

I wanted to like this game. It has a lot of things I like but it is too frustrating to play. I spent the first five hours of this game just figuring out how to play, finding a good path up the tech tree, creating an initial build queue and understanding the UI to be decent player. That's was OK because I thought after I had that down things would get better but as time went on it just left me on a plateau and I was no more satisfied than when I first figured out how to play.

Things I did enjoy- fitting your own ships with armor, weapons , subsystems and powergrid. Terraforming an ice planet turns it into an ocean planet. The artifacts are a nice touch and assimilation is very useful but comes too late in the tech tree becasue it is not retroactive.

My first successful empire was based on the good luck of finding a planet with 5 thought crystals. This gave and immense boost to my research abilities and I was quickly outpacing the computer. So whipped up a good ship design and threw it into production immediately and soon I had a decent size fleet ready to be mobilized on anything and I learned my first combat lesson just as quickly. Projectiles and missiles suck pretty hard in this game and energy beam weapons are way overpowered.

Why? Projectiles miss quite often and require ammo to use which means less space on your ship for armor/shield/powergrid mods and require resupply unless you have the painfully slow ammo fabricator. Missiles are slow and are easily avoidable if you maneuver your ships away from them and also require ammo. Beam weapons almost never miss (I had a beam weapon miss a few times when I paused the game and gave an order to attack then unpaused and the computer fired all weapons even though I was facing the opposite direction from my target? Still haven't figured that one out.) and require no ammo so making a good beam boat or two pretty much seals victory every time.
Also want to touch on the phased ordinance" tech here as this tech allows for a 50% chance of projectiles penetrating shields. You can unlock it twice so you can get 100% penetration but the first unlock is waaaay to early in the tree and there is only one other tech cheaper to start. It seems this was done to compensate for the low hit ratio of projectiles but it just breaks the game for shield users way early on. Don't even get me started on projectile armor penetration as well.

So I went back and rebuilt my ships with beams and ventured back out this time to steamroll everything in sight and that was pretty fun. After the initial wave of attacks I had reduced my enemies fleet to just freighters and they never seemed to recover. They never built another fleet of any size comparable to the first and this happened every time in every game I played with every race. You have one good fleet fight with the AI and its GG from them.

Also found out the hard way to never EVER press escape in the fitting window with the arcs overlay. I thought escape would drop the overlay and put you back to the fitting window while actually it will drop you from the fitting screen entirely without the chance to save your design. I always did the weapon arcs last so I lost a few good designs to an errant key press and I quit the games a few times doing that. The escape key is not consistent in the UI and lead me to believe it was more a "go back" button then a "close window" button.

And don't forget completely broken ground combat where if you take over from the AI and move your own guys it will allow your troops to automatically fire on each other as if they were the enemy and you have no way of stopping them until the unit dies!! Grrr!!!"

reviewText:
Could be fun, but has a non-existant tutorial. I had no clue how to design my ships, Plus you can't look at pre-made designs to get an idea or upgrade them. It does have a explanation area when you click the question mark, but it really don't explain much, especially about ship design.

Their idea of an epic sized galaxy is a joke. Also all planets are exactly the same size since they all had the exact amount of space to build on.

I had trouble with setting up fleets, after a while you get gargabe graphics and have to get out of the window to clear them. When adding ships to a fleet, they don't actually move into the fleet area until you move the fleet which makes no sense to me.

You have is a planet manager, however all you can do in it is to tell the AI what planets to colonize. You can't even use it to  move to individual planets. I had to scroll around on the map to find my home planet so i could give build orders.

Building anything is this game takes forever. My 3 hours of fame at 4x, all I managed to do is colonize roughly 20 planets and build some facilities and ships. There just doesn't seem like there is a lot of variety of buildings. Oh and you only get to build one of each on each planet.

I couldn't find a way to stop time, just hit random keys until something happened. Mostly ran is at 4x  until I got bored and quit.

I didn't understand a lot about this game and frankly I don't care, it's got too many issues to be a fun game. I was just bored or frustrated most of the time. Glad I got it in a bundle, sure as hell not worth the 30 bucks they're asking for it. Read somewhere that it was abandoned by it's dev for a sequal and that the sequal is just more like an update.

reviewText:
Wow. Stardrive. So sad. Early access is a double-edged sword. On one hand, you get to watch a promising game grow into something really special. On the other, you have Stardrive: A great concept lead by a thief. We were promised bug fixes, more content, and multiplayer. Instead, the dev took our money, discontinued development on this game, and moved on to Stardrive 2. He promises a 33% discount on the sequel for everyone who bought into his scheme. He will not be getting anymore of my money. It's a shame really as the game had a lot of potential.


As it stands Stardrive is okay. Not great. Not good. Just okay. A real-time 4x with fully customizable ships? Sounds awesome! It totally would be if it wasn't for all the game-breaking bugs, stupid AI, performance issues, and lack of multiplayer. All of which were promised to be addressed before the dev took our money and ran.

For around the same price you can grab countless other 4xs that are worth your time and are made by people deserving of your money. Let this game be a lesson to always be wary with early access titles.

reviewText:
This is one of those games with a lot of potential, and also one of those games that never quite lived up to it.

The premise is simple. The game takes place on a 2d plane. Your ships can be customized and designed very similar to Gratuitous Space Battles. Any wacky ship design you want, you can build. The game is also highly mod friendly, which is a huge plus in my book.

You colonize planets, design ships, build fleets, and conquer the galaxy. Simple enough.

Problem is that the game is highly buggy, full of memory leaks and other instabilities. This is a real shame considering how brilliant the game design is. There is just no polish and little to no bug fixing that was done. Be prepared to have your game either slow down to an unplayable crawl and/or crash to desktop continually.

Lots of potential but poor execution. Avoid this game unless you like frustration.

reviewText:
StarDrive is an immersive RPG. The amount that goes on in this game after a while starts to get crazy.

The concept is simple... zoom in and out with the mouse to view the star systems. The navigation that this game play provides is smooth and allows you to get to which system you need to view. The managing system of seeing all of your empires/planets and being able to allocate production is sophisticated enough but the user interface for it was done simply and made easy to use. Diplomacy can work for or sometimes quickly against you with an opposing empire declaring war. Trade routes, non-aggression pacts, war declaration, and even colony claims can be through diplomacy. Planets come in different varieties such as gas planets, Terran, swamp, barren and a few variants. Be sure to start exploring early and claim good planets, but doing so exposes you to aliens. You will find yourself addicted to this game after a while if you like micro and macro managing planets and a multitude of ships. You are also able to create your own ships (from colony ships to cruisers) and the creation system is a neat one at that. There is also an in game fleet design system that by itself makes the game much more easier to play (and to defend against enemies).

Why I support this game even though it has a lag issues (sometimes with and without the mod) is there is a community out there trying to improve this game. Moreover and more importantly for me, you are able to control a SINGLE UNIT and tell them what to fire. You can't say exactly which guns to use, but none the less this is the right idea in my mind to create a new genre : RPG meets first person shooters. Literally, any unit that's out there, choose to control. I wish more games did this in the sense. Imagine playing Starcraft and you can control a marine. Your marine that you are controlling dies so you automatically jump to the next one or go back to the RPG screen. This to me is brilliant and perhaps even game changing in the future.

I will have to give it a

RATING : 7.9/10

Due to lag issues and a need for a mod but either than that I recommend it - especially on sale. Just be extremely wary about the lag issue.

reviewText:
I love this game. When I bought it I just left it and never played for about 6 months. But when I picked it up and modded it with Tim's mod,  couldn't stop playing, I haven't had any problems with it, though that might just be because I have a gtx970. And with that mod it was amazing. reviewText:
Stardrive is a really good game, though with a few rough edges.  It seems to run fine until late game area where it will lag (on any computer) a good deal.

The develoment is done for it unfortunatly but you can get the blackbox un-official patches from https://bitbucket.org/CrunchyGremlin/sd-idk/overview

Blackbox is still pumping out updates to make the game better and better.  I would have liked to see some multiplayer though or even some more fleshed out storyline (the game has a kind of story you can figure out as you play).

The races you meet have very unique looks, especially the space samuri bears.  The ships look and feel amazing and each one can be totally customized and upgraded with research and the shipyard.  With stardrive 2 coming out soon though I might just hold off buying this one and get the sequel (which should have much more added in).
All in all I will be buying the sequel, so that should tell you how much I like this game.

reviewText:
I have been playing this game since its beta release and i think its fair to say this game could have been so much more

“Some omissions and flaws, but balanced by excellent alien races and ship design. A welcome addition to the crew.”

this says it all nicely but is largely understated. As a whole the management and construction of an empire works quite well but in combination with wonky AI; a civ 5-esque diplomacy screen with reduced options and strange reactions (allies will quickly turn hostile if the wrong trade is proposed); no counterspying option leaves you to get ravaged by enemy spies; many incomplete or just missing features; no multiplayer; and late-game performance issues (I play it on a laptop so it may just be that) the fun factor quickly turns to frustration late in the game.

A lot of features were also just left out, despite being advertised as either implemented or coming soon on the steam store, and will most likely never be implemented as Zero Sum basically dropped everything in development for the game and focused on the production of a sequel, leaving the first game feeling very incomplete

BUT there are many aspects that work quite well:

The shipyard feature, for example, is amazing. it allows you to arrange unlocked systems on a ship frame so you can create specialized designs (ie resupply, strike, scout, coloyization etc) and allows you to control thier performance levels.
too many systems bogs down the power supply, shields over armor can be a vulnurability and more massive means slower travel. to name a few things.

the game is visually stunning. you are able to scale the map from a galactic map down to a single star with orbiting planets. the alien races are all fantastically concieved and there are 8 playable races which can be customized to have a number of positive and negative traits upon starting a new game. each race has its own ship designs, and most of them have unique ground units

I really liked that this game was 4x so that The game flows continuously and allows space battles to occur in real time while the construction and research aspects are turn based progressions. i thought this system worked really well, especially since you can increase the time scaling up to 4x (or more, but not on my laptop) and speed up the slow early stages of the game.


Unfortunately the features that i liked did not make up for its short comings, for me at least, and it looks like they will be carried through to the sequel along with countless improvements/features that should have been in this game.

VERDICT: this game is not worth $33CAD
If this game appeals to you, then I would wait for the sequel
If you've read a fair number of reviews and still want to try it, then wait for a sale to drop the price to $5-10 as there are some mods out there that really add a lot to the game and the game is still enjoyable

reviewText:
This game involved a lot of really great ideas, all with terrible execution, clunky control, and a UI that makes you want to gougue your eyes out.


Ship design in this game might be the deepest ever attempted, but involves far more tedious wiring of power than engineering acumen. You'd almost certainly enjoy Star Ruler's much simpler scheme, which ends up achieving far more creative possibility, or GalCiv and skip the hour-long battleship design process entirely.

Automation? Sounds good, but the AI is pretty terrible at minding itself. If you want to get much done, you're forced to take it into your own hands, and deal with the horrid hotkeys, UI, and the rediculous WASD-control of ships, which makes them unavailable for scrolling around the map. You also can't click-drag. You're stuck with arrow keys or zoom-popping like a schizophrenic rabbit. If you want your empire to do its own thing(but also the way you tell it to), play Distant Worlds, because that game has true and almost total automation options that is as capable as the actual enemy AI(which can get rather brutal, unlike stardrive's rather easy bots).

Ship combat doesn't even look that good, or play well. If you want something with tactics, go play MOO, and if you want actual cinematic splosion glory, go GalCiv or endless space. Small ships are gross pixel blobs and large ships just tend to look like a bunch of sausages flopping around.

There is very little customization available other than the standard race min/maxing before a game starts. Want to slog through a massive galaxy of mostly barren worlds? nope. Want a quick fight between factions already up against each other's shoulders? too bad. Square maps that all play the same. Why not any other game I previously listed, some allowing you to play on 3-d barbell, spherical, or perpedicular galactic arrangements while all allow much more map control. Why was this overlooked?

So even if you actually get used to panning around on the arrow keys like a geriatric, navigate your way through obtuse and uninformative UI, and after spending hours plugging your ship's weapons into power sockets, what do you get? Well, you'll be dealing with micromanagement forever. Yep, like Civ5 lategame, but more like all game. Governors are idiots, and basically anything you want to do you're going to have to pause the game and painstakingly order it out so that fleet doesn't fly apart in transit and make sure you pay attention to your ground forces so they don't sit there for days doing nothing!

You don't so much play this game as try to bear it. No matter what your tastes, what you really want is something else.

reviewText: Multiplayer would make this game amazing, as would the ability to make an actual custom race (as opposed to customizing the races as presented). Even lacking these things, it makes for a fun game. It can take civilization levels of time to complete a game though, if you decide to go for all the races and maximum map size.\nAll that said, I would suggest definately getting this game if you can pick it up for 20 bucks or less. If you are a particular fan of space 4x type games, then paying full price isn't out of the question. Having control of building your ships And commanding them in combat is very nice.
voteText: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Star Drive

This is a pretty decent game. It runs in real time as do the space battles. Ships can be commanded in space battles for full control of targeting.

Ship design is really neat. Hulls come as is and may be filled with all sorts of space combat goodies. THis is a cool part of the game.

Tech research is pretty neat. There are not a lot of techs but what is there is good.

The alien races are all distinct and filled with personality. There is also cusomization for your race if you want it.

The developer moved on to their next game, Star Drive 2, and they are very active in that title. This game has all that is needed to wage war and conquer the stars. It may be missing some fleshed out things but the game is definitely playable and fun.

Oh, and ground battles are turn based with control over each troop. Pretty cool.

reviewText: A lack of a good tutorial makes this game very difficult to get into. Any 4X, complex strategy game should put a lot of effort into their tutorial otherwise they outcast newcomers to the genre. I'm not a veteran 4X gamer, but I've played my fair share. I eventually did sort of get the hang of everything, but the fact that I was forced to learn mostly manually made my choices very stilted and boring. Like I didn't want to declare war on anybody since I didn't really understand if I'd win or not. I also focused solely on economy because everything else seemed a bit more advanced.\n\nThat said, the game was pretty decent, I just have zero interest in learning a new 4X game without proper learning tools. I'll go back and play SoaSE before I play this again.
